XHU v XHV

XHU v XHV
[2025] SGFC 23

Case Number:Divorce No 182 of 2024 (Summons No 3441 of 2024)
Decision Date:27 February 2025
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Soh Kian Peng
Counsel Name(s): Sabrina Wong Xue Yun, Wong Soo Chih (SC Wong Chambers LLC) for the plaintiff; the defendant in person and unrepresented.
Parties: XHU — XHV

Family Law – Costs

27 February 2025

Judgment reserved

Assistant Registrar Soh Kian Peng:

1       This is my decision on the costs of SUM 3441/2024 (“SUM 3441”) which was the Husband’s application for discovery. My decision in respect of SUM 3441 can be found in XHU v ZHV [2025] SGFC 11.

2       Counsel for the Wife argues that the Husband should have to pay the Wife costs, fixed at $2000 (all-in). They say that the Husband’s application in SUM 3441 was unmeritorious and had “unnecessarily or unreasonably protracted, or added to the costs or complexity of” the divorce proceedings. They also emphasise that the Husband had not pursued his discovery request in good faith.[note: 1]

3       The Husband, on the other hand, after having been reminded to put in his submissions on the costs of SUM 3441, stated that he did “not have any cost to claim”.[note: 2]

4       Where costs are concerned, it is well-established that costs shall follow the event, though the court can depart from this starting point if the circumstances of the case justify doing so: VVB v VVA [2022] SGHCF 1 at [9] and [10] citing Rule 852 and 854 of the Family Justice Rules 2014; XCR v XCS [2024] SGFC 84 at [4] citing WXE v WXF [2024] SGFC 40 at [7] – [8].

5       In the present case, the Wife is entitled to costs. That is because she had successfully resisted the Husband’s application for discovery in SUM 3441. The Husband did not manage to obtain the orders which he sought in SUM 3441.

6       As to the quantum of such costs, that shall be fixed at $600 (all-in). In fixing the quantum of such costs, I take into account the fact that the Husband had only sought discovery in respect of two items, and that the affidavits and submissions were not particularly voluminous. While counsel for the Wife argues that his application was unmeritorious and that it was not taken out in good faith, they have not set out why this is the case, apart from pointing to the fact that this is evident from the Husband’s “haphazard application and pleadings”. In any event, I do not find that the Husband’s conduct warrants an upwards adjustment in the quantum of such costs to be awarded.

7       It is therefore ordered that the Husband shall pay the Wife the sum of $600, being the costs of SUM 3441. This shall be done no later than 10 April 2025.

[note: 1]Wife’s Written Submissions dated 11 February 2025.

[note: 2]Husband’s email to court dated 24 February 2025.

XHS v XHT

XHS v XHT
[2025] SGFC 20

Case Number:D 1052/2021 (FC/SUM 1760/2023)
Decision Date:20 February 2025
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Chia Wee Kiat
Counsel Name(s): Ms Pearlyn Yeo Qi Yan (Yeo & Associates LLC) for the plaintiff; Ms Roqiyah Begum (Netto and Magin LLC) for the defendant.
Parties: XHS — XHT

Family Law – Division of matrimonial assets – Setting aside of consent order – Variation of consent order

Family Law – Child – Care and control – Setting aside of consent order – Variation of consent order

Family Law – Child – Maintenance – Setting aside of consent order – Variation of consent order

20 February 2025

District Judge Chia Wee Kiat:

Background

1       The plaintiff (the “Husband”) and the defendant (the “Wife”) were married on 6 March 2011.[note: 1] The Husband works as a deputy manager[note: 2], and the Wife a lecturer.[note: 3] The parties have a boy, [T], who is aged 13 this year.[note: 4]

2       The Husband filed for divorce on 8 March 2021 under the simplified track.[note: 5] Interim Judgment (“IJ”) was granted on 6 April 2021.[note: 6] Under clause 3 of the IJ, the parties agreed to the following orders (“Consent Order”):

By Consent:

a.    That the Plaintiff and the Defendant be granted joint custody of the child of the marriage, namely [T], with care and control to the Plaintiff.

b.    The Defendant shall have access to the child of the marriage including but not limited to the following:

(i)    Monday 5.30 pm to 8 pm;

(ii)   Wednesday 5.30 pm to 8 pm;

(iii)   Friday 5.30 pm to Saturday 5 pm.

c.    The Defendant’s rights, title and interests in the matrimonial property known as [Property A] shall be transferred (other than by way of sale) to the Plaintiff upon the Plaintiff making the full required CPF refunds into the Defendant’s CPF account(s) and no cash consideration, within six (6) months from the date of the Final Judgment. All expenses relating to the transfer (including conveyancing, stamp, registration and administrative fees of the transfer) shall be borne by the Plaintiff solely. Upon effect of the transfer of the matrimonial property, the outstanding loan (if any) and all expenses relating to the matrimonial property will be borne by the Plaintiff entirely.

d.    The sum of $200,000.00 in parties’ fixed deposit shall be divided equally between the Plaintiff and Defendant.

e.    There shall be no maintenance for the Defendant.

f.    The Plaintiff shall maintain the child of the marriage solely.

g.    (a) The Registrar and/or Assistant Registrar of the Family Justic Courts under Section 31 of the Family Justice Act (No. 27 of 2014) is empowered to execute, sign or indorse all necessary documents relating to matters contained in this order on behalf of either party should either party fail to do so within seven (7) days of written request being made to the party.

(b)    The Plaintiff and the Defendant agree to set up a fund for the child with a deposit of $130,000.00. Mutual written agreement needs to be sought in order to use the said fund. In the future, the Defendant will do a 1-to-1 match deposit to the fund with the Plaintiff if needed.

(c)    The Plaintiff and the Defendant shall each retain all other assets in his/her own names.

(d)    That neither the Plaintiff nor the Defendant shall have any further claim against each other.

(e)    That the above terms shall be in full and final settlement of parties’ claims against each other.

(f)    That there be liberty to apply.

3       The IJ was made final on 9 July 2021. [note: 7]

4       On 2 June 2023, the Wife filed FC/SUM 1706/2023 (“SUM 1706”) seeking, inter alia, the following orders:

To set aside/vary Clauses 3(a) to (g) of the Interim Judgment dated 6 April 2021 (FC/IJ 1555/2021) (the “IJ”) in respect of the consent orders relating to custody, care and control, maintenance for child, division of matrimonial assets (including matrimonial flat).

5       The Wife alleged that the child would “continue to experience verbal and emotional mistreatment, which is a primary motive behind this application.”[note: 8]

6       In brief, the Wife wanted:[note: 9]

(a)     care and control of the child;

(b)     reasonable amount of maintenance for the child; and

(c)     the division of matrimonial assets to be redetermined.

7       SUM 1706 came up for hearing before me on 27 August 2024. In light of the issues raised by parties with respect to [T], I called for a Custody Evaluation Report (“CER”) and reserved my decision.

8       Having received the CER, I fixed the matter for decision on 27 December 2024, which was re-fixed to 13 January 2025 at parties’ request. Shortly before the date of decision, the Wife’s counsel wrote a letter dated 2 January 2025 to the court to “highlight the Plaintiff’s ongoing and hostile conduct”. This invited a reply dated 8 January 2025 from the Husband refuting the Wife’s allegations as “a blatant attempt to mislead the court”. The Wife responded with a rebuttal dated 10 January 2025 “to address the Plaintiff’s numerous misleading and unsubstantiated allegations”.

9       At the resumed hearing on 13 January 2025, I reminded counsel that when the court had reserved judgment as I had done in this case, no new evidence should be presented without the leave of court: see VYP v VYQ [2021] SGHCF 40 (at [36]). I also reminded counsel that it was a discourtesy to the court to make further submission without seeking leave: see VEW v VEV [2022] SGCA 34 (at [9]). As these letters were presented to the court after judgment was reserved, I made it clear that I did not consider the contents of the letters in reaching my decision.

10     When giving my decision, I provided brief grounds to parties and indicated that these might be elaborated on and supplemented with fuller grounds if required. As the Wife has appealed the whole of my decision vide HCF/DCA 8/2025 filed on 24 January 2025, I set out below my full grounds of decision.

Division of matrimonial assets

11     I begin with the Wife’s application to “set aside/vary” the Consent Order in relation to the division of matrimonial assets. The starting point is s 112(4) of the Women’s Charter 1961 (“the Charter”), which provides that the court “may, at any time, it thinks fit, extend, vary, revoke or discharge any order made under this section, and may vary any term or condition upon or subject to which any such order has been made”.

12     The Husband submitted that the Wife’s application was confusing as it was not entirely clear if the Wife was trying to set aside the Consent Order or vary the Consent Order.[note: 10]

13     I agreed that clarity was important as the thresholds for setting aside and varying a consent order in relation to the division of matrimonial assets are different. Moreover, the Wife’s application went beyond the division of matrimonial assets. It extended to the setting aside and variation of orders in relation to custody, care and control and child maintenance, for which different provisions and considerations apply. Yet, the entirety of the Wife’s submissions was premised on s 112(4) of the Charter, which is applicable only to the division of matrimonial assets. This was unsatisfactory as it obfuscated the issues that had to be determined by the court.

14     Notwithstanding the deficiency in the Wife’s submissions, I gave careful consideration to the merits of her application in accordance with the applicable provisions and relevant case law with respect to each area of her application.

Whether the Consent Order should be set aside

15     The threshold for setting aside a consent order relating to the division of matrimonial assets was set out in Lee Min Jai v Chua Chew Koon [2005] 1 SLR (R) 548 (“Lee Min Jai”) and discussed in AOO v AON [2011] 4 SLR1169 (at [10]) and AYM v AYL [2013] 1 SLR 924 (“AYM v AYL”) (at [17]).[note: 11] As noted in Lee Min Jai (at [6]), “[a] court would interfere with an order of court obtained by consent, only on just and equitable grounds”.[note: 12] Choo Han Teck J explained (at [5]) as follows:

Under s 112(4) of the Women’s Charter (Cap 353, 1997 Rev Ed), the court “may, at any time it thinks fit, extend, vary, revoke or discharge any order made under this section, and may vary any term or condition upon or subject to which any such order has been made”. But this section, and the authorities referred to by Mr Chia, should not be construed as an invitation to revise the terms of a settlement merely so that they appear more equitable or will be, in fact, more equitable in the objective opinion of the court. Privately settled terms in respect of the ancillary matters in a divorce may not always appear to be fair. But divorce is a very personal matter, and each party would have his own private reasons for demanding, or acquiescing, to any given term or condition in the ultimate settlement. What the court should be alert to, is that one party had not taken an unfair advantage over the other in the course of negotiating and settling the terms. Hence, in Dean v Dean [1978] 3 All ER 758, the court held (as set out in the headnote) that:

[W]here an agreement between the parties had been reached at arm’s length and the parties had been separately advised, the agreement itself would be prima facie evidence of the reasonableness of its terms, and formal discovery would probably be unnecessary.

16     Hence, to set aside a consent order on the division of matrimonial assets under s 112(4) of the Charter, an applicant must prove one of the vitiating factors: see UMM v UML [2018] SGHCF 13 (at [8]).[note: 13] A vitiating factor is a contractual doctrine that includes misrepresentation, mistake, undue influence, duress, unconscionability, as well as illegality and public policy: see TR v TQ [2009] 2 SLR (R) (at [97]). While the precise application of each of the vitiating factors to consent orders made in the matrimonial context has not been definitively decided (see AYM v AYL (at [15])), some of the reasons that have been cited in setting-aside applications include duress, misrepresentation and undue influence: for example, see UMM v UML and ATZ v AUA [2015] SGHC 161 (“ATZ v AUA”) (at [22]). In addition, the absence of full and frank disclosure of material facts by one of the parties may also result in a consent order being set aside: see AYM v AYL (at [31]).[note: 14]

17     In the present case, the Wife claimed that the Consent Order was obtained through “duress, undue influence and misrepresentation” which severely compromised her ability to make a free and informed decision.[note: 15] She sought to set aside the Consent Order on grounds that she categorized as follows: (a) misrepresentation; (b) duress and undue influence; and (c) emotional and psychological coercion.[note: 16]

18     Having carefully considered the evidence before me, I found that the Wife did not satisfy the requisite threshold to set aside the Consent Order. I elaborate on my reasons below, adopting the categories framed by the Wife.

Misrepresentation

(1)   False Legal representation

19     The Wife alleged that the Husband had falsely claimed that the appointed lawyer was acting on behalf of both parties and yet consistently denied the Wife’s requests to communicate directly with the lawyer. This left the Wife without proper legal representation, making her vulnerable to the Husband’s exploitation.[note: 17] In support of her claim, she reproduced the following WhatsApp messages:[note: 18]

2/9/21, 6:58 PM – [H]: It’s our lawyer, basically draft based on what we agree. You want time slot, put in. You want cpf refund, I put in. You want joint account to spell out, I put in.

2/9/21, 6:59 PM – [H]: Ok, then I ask them to draft, you can ask them as you are also the client.

20     The Husband’s position was that there was no such false representation. The involvement of the lawyer was limited to merely drafting the terms based on the discussions between the parties themselves. The Husband said that he was not well versed in legal terminology and mistakenly believed that engaging a lawyer was to ensure the proper handling of all necessary paperwork. During the meeting at his lawyer’s office, it was explicitly stated that the lawyer represented him alone, and the clauses in the IJ were drafted pursuant to parties’ private negotiations and agreement.[note: 19] The Wife was apprised of her right to seek independent legal advice but made a personal decision not to personally engage a lawyer.[note: 20]

21     Further, the Husband said that the Wife had not presented the complete WhatsApp message.[note: 21] He reproduced the following extracts:[note: 22]

[W]    I am uncomfortable with your lawyer, only acting in your benefit without any consideration for [T]

I am already giving you care and control part … all the house and car

who is squeezing who

[H]    It’s our lawyer, basically draft based on what we agree. You want time slot, put in. You want cpf refund, I put in. You want joint account to spell out, I put in.

[W]    all I am asking is to spell out clearly not to have any misunderstanding …

22     As noted by the learned authors in Halsbury’s Laws of Singapore – Contract (Volume 7) (LexisNexis) at [80.172]:

Misrepresentation refers to an untrue or misleading statement that induces the formation of a contract. It may operate as an important defence in the hands of a representee to vitiate a contract …

23     As elaborated at [80.189]:

An essential ingredient of an operative misrepresentation is that it influenced or induced the representee in his decision to enter into the contract. There would be no inducement if the representee did not know of the representation or was aware of its untruth or was not influenced by it, as where he would have entered into the contract even had he known the true facts or where he relied on his own judgment or investigations. Inducement refers to the causal relation, which is a question of fact, between the representation and action on the part of the representee to act.

24     The WhatsApp message produced by the Wife showed that the Husband had represented to her that the lawyer was “our lawyer” and that “you are also the client”. While this was prima facie a misrepresentation, I found no evidence to suggest that it was fraudulently made. When the Wife attended at the lawyer’s office, she was told that the lawyer represented the Husband alone. This was evident from the acknowledgement signed by the Wife in the presence of a Commissioner for Oaths, which stated as follows:[note: 23]

I acknowledge that I have considered the terms of the agreement and have also been informed of my right to seek independent legal advice.

25     The Wife had considered the terms of the agreement and was informed of her right to seek independent legal advice. Given these undisputed facts, the Wife could not be laboring under any misapprehension when she entered into the agreement. The misrepresentation was corrected and could not have influenced or induced her at the material time.

26     Moreover, there was ample evidence to show that the Wife had exercised her own judgment in her negotiations with the Husband. This was borne out by her affidavit, examples of which are reproduced below:[note: 24]

Para 51.

However, when I received the first draft of the divorce documents, I noticed that my access to [T] was stated as “reasonable access”. I confronted the Plaintiff and requested to change the term “reasonable access” to “equal access”… I disagree and demand the equal access as suggested earlier.

Para 52.

When I received the 2nd draft divorce document, the access arrangement was still the same. I confronted the Plaintiff. I requested for liberal access. Finally, parties agreed to “schedule access and reasonable access”.

Para 54.

I confronted the Plaintiff as to his intention of limiting my access as mentioned above. The Plaintiff claimed that he had asked the lawyer to indicate schedule access and reasonable access and claimed that they have missed it.

Para 55.

… I had to repeatedly ask him to include the following: “The Defendant shall have reasonable access to the child of the marriage including at least the following …

Para 56.

The Plaintiff agreed and the same was included in the draft consent order …

Para 67.

During the divorce period, the Defendant’s (sic) initial proposal was to utilize the $200,000 to pay off my CPF monies in which the balance monies of around $70,000 is to be distributed equally. However, I disagreed.

Para 68.

Eventually, parties agreed that the Plaintiff will reimburse my CPF monies utilized for the purchase of the matrimonial flat separately and distribute the monies in the said account equally between parties.

Para 70.

In the Plaintiff’s first few drafts of the divorce documents, the Plaintiff refused to refund my CPF monies utilized for the purchase of the matrimonial flat upon me transferring the matrimonial flat to his name. However, when I found out that in the event, I transfer the matrimonial flat to the Plaintiff’s sole name without him refunding my CPF monies, it would put me into a huge CPF debt of estimated $130,000, I confronted him of the same …

Para 72:

As I did not want to be thrown into six-figure debt with HDB, I had to keep insisting for full CPF refund.

Para 75:

… I refused and demanded that the Plaintiff do a full refund of my CPF monies. The Plaintiff finally agreed to do so …

Para 80.

I proposed the Plaintiff to match my $130,000 amount to make this account $260,000 that cannot be used for [T] living expense nor education …

[Emphasis in bold added]



27     It was clear from the above extracts that the Wife had no difficulty confronting the Husband over matters she disagreed with, would not compromise when she needed to stand firm, was capable of making proposals of her own and possessed the clarity of mind to make considered decisions. Clearly, she was exercising independent judgment. There was no causal relation as such between the misrepresentation and her decision to enter into the agreement.

28     The Wife claimed that without proper legal representation, she was vulnerable to the Husband’s exploitation. The Wife alleged that the Husband exploited her limited knowledge of Singapore’s divorce laws and her cultural background from Thailand, where women’s rights were less protected.[note: 25]

29     However, it was undisputed that she was informed of her right to seek independent legal advice. It was her prerogative to seek help if she needed assistance. It would be inequitable for the Wife to blame the Husband for her lack of legal representation when she could have taken reasonable steps to obtain independent legal advice.

30     As was similarly observed by Debbie Ong J (as she then was) in UMM v UML (at [10]):

Starting with the arguments on the Husband’s capacity to appreciate the documents before him, if the Husband genuinely did not understand the terms of the 1st DCO, he could have sought assistance or expressed that he needed more time to consider them. As noted by the DJ, the Husband is educated, and held the rank of First Warrant Officer in the Singapore Armed Forces before his retirement. I also observe that more than a year elapsed between his signing of the 1st and 2nd DCOs. I emphasise that it is a serious matter for one to sign a legal document before a Commissioner of Oaths or before a lawyer.

31     More pertinently, the picture that emerged from her evidence and the contemporaneous WhatsApp messages between the parties was simply incongruous with the case she tried to make out to the court. I found her to be assertive, and she certainly did not come across as one who could be easily induced, influenced, coerced or exploited. The fact that she was able to get the Husband to concede to her demands spoke for itself.

32     Finally, it should be noted that in a WhatsApp message to the Husband, the Wife herself had acknowledged that “we had good amicable agreement”.[note: 26] This message was sent on 27 September 2021,[note: 27] five months after the Consent Order was recorded. It put beyond doubt that the Husband had not taken any unfair advantage over her in the course of negotiating and settling the terms, and that the agreement reached was consensual. In light of all the evidence, it seemed more likely that the Wife was seeking to take advantage of the innocent misrepresentation by the Husband to advance her case.

(2)   Deception in Custody/Access Matters

33     The Wife also alleged that the Husband misled her about the feasibility of shared custody and control of their child.[note: 28] In support of her claim, she reproduced the following extracts:[note: 29]

2/28/21, 9.18 PM

-

[W]: please change to joint care and control

2/28/21, 9.18 PM

–

[W]: I won’t sign

2/28/21, 9.22 PM

–

[H]: It can’t be done

2/28/21, 9.23 PM

–

[H]: So far I am very reasonable, trying work out the best for all

2/3/21, 12:01 PM

–

[W]: 2. Change Citizenship Education Level

 

 

6.

7b. Change to SHARED care and control

7c. Change reasonable access to EQUAL access

2/3/21, 1:20 PM

–

[H]: Missed voice call

2/3/21, 2.17 PM

–

[H]: https://singaporelegaladvice.com/law-articles/the-guide-to-child-custody-in-singapore/

2/3/21, 2.18 PM

–

[H]: Differences between child custody and care and control

Custody should be distinguished from care and control of the child. Child custody grants the custodial parent(s) authority in making major decisions regarding their child. Some of these decisions include matters concerning education, religion and healthcare of the child.

On the other hand, care and control is only given to one parent, who will be involved in the child’s day-to-day matters. The other parent not given care and control will be granted access to the child for certain periods.



34     The Husband submitted that the Wife demonstrated a clear understanding of the law at the material time, as demonstrated by the communication sent to her one month prior to the signing of the divorce document.[note: 30] She was a highly educated individual and an educator at the tertiary level.[note: 31] She was apprised of her right to seek independent legal advice from the beginning but made a conscious decision not to personally engage a lawyer. [note: 32]

35     I found it harsh for the Wife to accuse the Husband of deception when it was evident that he had relied on materials obtained from a legal website which he had provided her with the link. There was nothing to prevent her from visiting the website and verifying the information for herself.

36     Moreover, it was reasonable to infer that the Wife had some knowledge of the law, as she had specifically asked to change the term in the draft agreement to shared care and control, which is a legal construct used by the court to make arrangements to support families where the child’s parents have separated: see TAU v TAT [2018] SGHCF 11 (at [10] – [12]). The Wife would have known that the court may grant both parents shared care and control as she had specifically asked to change the term in the draft agreement to “SHARED care and control”. If there was any doubt in her mind about the legal position, she could have sought independent legal advice if the issue was of concern to her. As noted in Lee Min Jai (at [5]):

… divorce is a very personal matter, and each party would have his own private reasons for demanding, or acquiescing, to any given term or condition in the ultimate settlement.

37     As the Wife was prepared, for her own private reasons, to acquiesce to sole care and control without seeking independent legal advice, it would be inequitable for her to accuse the Husband of deception, especially when she knew that he had relied on materials obtained from a legal website.

(3)   Deception in Financial Matters

38     The Wife also alleged that the Husband had concealed his personal assets and directed her attention solely towards certain shared assets, preventing her from seeing the full picture of their financial situation.[note: 33] She listed the following matrimonial assets that were not included in the IJ:[note: 34]

a.     Monies in parties CPF accounts

b.     Parties’ matrimonial car estimated value of $90,000.

c.     Singapore Savings Bond of estimated $90,000 belonging to the Plaintiff and $30,000 belonging to [the Wife].

d.     Cash in hand at home amounting to an estimated value of SGD$3,000 (foreign currency).

e.     Plaintiff’s savings account in China bank and other savings accounts in his sole name which [the Wife] have no knowledge of.

f.     Plaintiff’s Multiplier account.

g.     Plaintiff’s insurance policies and investment accounts.

h.     Other valuables estimated to be worth $10,000 (i.e jewelleries which the Plaintiff’s mother gifted to [the Wife] during the marriage, exercise bike, piano, household appliances/furniture).

39     She submitted that the absence of full and frank disclosure of material facts by one of the parties might result in a consent order being set aside by the court.[note: 35]

40     In response, the Husband pointed out that the Wife had a S$85,5000 Singapore saving bond under her name[note: 36], a multiplier account which had approximately S$50,000[note: 37] and insurance policy and investment account,[note: 38] and she had drawn S$3,000 annually from the family fund to either save into her Thai bank account or her relative’s bank account to keep the cash somewhere which he did not know about.[note: 39] There were no jewelleries except a wedding ring which the Wife had already taken away.[note: 40] The assets listed in the IJ were the main matrimonial assets.[note: 41]

41     I found no merits in the Wife’s allegations. Firstly, it was contemplated in clause 3g(c) of the IJ that the parties “shall each retain all other assets in his/her own names.” It should be noted that these “other assets” included assets in her sole name, such as monies in her CPF account and bank accounts, which were within her knowledge. Hence, she could not be oblivious that there were other assets that were not expressly listed in the IJ. Indeed, the whole point of clause 3g(c) was to allow the parties to retain these “other assets” in his or her sole name. In addition, the parties had also agreed to clause 3(g)(d) which made it clear that neither party “shall have any further claim against each other”. In short, the fact that the Wife was able to produce a list of matrimonial assets that were not expressly included in the IJ was not a basis by itself to set aside the Consent Order.

42     Secondly, if the complete accounting of assets was important to her, she could have requested that parties exchange a list of assets before agreeing to clause 3g(c) of the IJ, bearing in mind that the duty of full and frank disclosure cuts both ways. If she had done so and there was non-disclosure on the part of the Husband, she would be amply justified to set aside the Consent Order. But that was not the case here. The Wife was content to accept clause 3g(c) without the need for mutual disclosure. Contrary to her submissions, there was no concealment, let alone deception.

(4)   Duress and undue influence

43     The Wife submitted that that the Husband exerted undue influence over her by repeatedly pressuring her to agree to the Consent Order, using emotional manipulation and threats. She said that the Husband had insisted that if she did not agree to give him sole care and control of their child, he might remove himself from their lives, leaving the child without a father. The Husband also pressured the Wife during her busy work hours and claimed that he might only have a few years left to live. [note: 42]

44     The Husband said that in the interest of promoting the child’s wellbeing, he agreed to joint custody as requested by the Wife. However, joint custody entailed fulfilling responsibilities towards the child, which the Wife had often failed to recognise. For example, in February 2021, when he enrolled the child in a preparatory course for the Gifted Education Program and personally covered the cost of $4,846, cooperation from the Wife was extremely challenging.[note: 43]

45     The Husband said that the Wife was well aware that granting care and control to him was in the best interests of the child.[note: 44] The child’s wellbeing had been diligently attended to over the past three years.[note: 45] The Husband implemented long-term plans to secure the child’s present and future needs, including relocating to a more conducive residence in preparation for the Primary School Leaving Examination, procuring property to cater to the child’s post-primary education requirements, and supplementing the joint account with additional funds to endure the child’s educational aspirations were adequately supported.[note: 46] Testimonies from school teachers during teacher seminars affirmed the child’s happiness at school and flourishing social relationships.[note: 47]

46     In ATZ v AUA, the court made the following observations (at [22]):

… it is normally the case (as in the present) that parties to a marriage would invoke the doctrines of undue influence or duress to set aside a marital agreement, given the emotionally charged circumstances in which such agreements are normally negotiated and executed. The existence of independent legal advice would normally be a strong indication of informed consent, which would undermine arguments relating to undue influence or duress.

47     In the present case, while the Wife was not legally advised in the entry into the agreement, she was informed of her right to seek independent legal advice. In the same vein, this would undermine her arguments relating to undue influence and duress.

48     Moreover, as noted earlier, there was ample evidence to show that the Wife had exercised her judgment independently. In her own words, “we had good amicable settlement”. This could not be the case if she had felt pressured by the Husband to enter into an agreement she did not agree to.

(5)   Emotional and psychological coercion

49     The Wife also alleged that the Husband employed coercive and manipulative tactics during the divorce process to pressure the Wife into agreeing to an unfair settlement. The Wife claimed that the Husband avoided creating written evidence of his actions by insisting on verbal communications, leaving the Wife emotionally distressed after each interaction. The Husband played on the Wife’s compassion and vulnerability by making unverified claims about his health and resorted to deception, false blame, and threats throughout the process.[note: 48]

50     The picture painted by the Wife was that of a conniving husband taking advantage of a vulnerable spouse. However, this picture did not cohere with the objective evidence. Firstly, if the Husband had wanted to avoid creating written evidence, the Wife’s affidavits could not be replete with numerous written communications of their negotiations and related matters which she had relied on extensively in support of her case.[note: 49] The Wife had also made use of some of these statements to disparage him.

51     Secondly, as explained earlier, I found that the Wife had exercised her judgment independently in negotiating and settling the terms of the agreement.

52     Thirdly, in her supporting affidavit, the Wife averred as follows:[note: 50]

… The Plaintiff created the illusion that my choices were voluntary. However, upon closer examination, I now realize that the Plaintiff deliberately orchestrated the entire divorce “discussion” toward unfair outcome for me.

[emphasis in bold added].

53     On closer examination, it would become apparent that this was an admission by the Wife that she had had entered into the agreement voluntarily at the material time. This is because it was only “now” and “upon closer examination” that she realised that she had been coerced. That being the case, she could not have acted under coercion when she entered into the agreement, as this would involve a diametrically opposite state of mind.

54     Indeed, in another part of her affidavit, the Wife had also stated that it was “[o]nly in hindsight” that she “came to realize” that she was coerced into signing the agreement.[note: 51] Hence, the case advanced by the Wife appeared to be an ex post facto attempt to conjure up a case of coercion when, based on her own admissions, none existed at the material time.

55     Finally, as noted earlier, the Wife had in a WhatsApp message to the Husband acknowledged that “we had good amicable settlement”. This put beyond doubt that she had acted on her free will and was not coerced into signing the agreement.

Summary

56     For the reasons set out above, I found that the requisite threshold for setting aside the Consent Order was not met. To sum up this part of my grounds, the following observations of Choo Han Teck J in VWQ v VWR [2022] SGHCF 5 (at [9]) bear reiterating:

… Generally, a consent order is a contract negotiated and agreed upon by parties, and the courts would be slow to re-write their contract. Privately settled terms negotiated by the parties, especially in family matters are to be encouraged. As such, they should be respected, and not lightly changed. Otherwise, one party may lead the other to believe that obtaining a consent order would end their dispute, only to call in aid the provisions in the Women’s Charter to vary their agreement (TOC v TOD [2016] SGHCF 10) when they feel that the bargain was not to their liking subsequently.

57     As also noted in UMM v UML (at [12]), the need for finality is a significant consideration:

… it must not be forgotten that consent orders are the end of a process of “give-and-take” to harmoniously resolve a dispute between parties. There is another party, the Wife in this case, who has participated in negotiations towards an agreement and who has relied on the resolution process to move on from this dispute. The need for finality is a significant consideration: see AYM at [12].

Whether the Consent Order should be varied

58     I turn next to the Wife’s application to vary the Consent Order.

59     In AYM v AYL (at [15] and [22]–[23]), the Court of Appeal made it clear that s 112(4) was not intended to confer upon the court a jurisdiction writ large, but a limited flexibility to adjust an order for the division of matrimonial assets already made. This would be, a fortiori, the case when the order of court was premised upon a consent order entered into between the parties themselves. Once the order of court with respect to the division of matrimonial assets had been completely implemented or spent inasmuch as everything that was required to be done had been effected and the assets concerned had in fact been distributed to the parties concerned, the court did not have the power to revisit or reopen the order. Where the order for the division of matrimonial assets made by the court had not been completely effected or implemented, the court would make, inter alia, the necessary variations to an order for division of matrimonial assets only when the order was unworkable or had become unworkable.

60     As the case put forward by the Wife did not show that the Consent Order was unworkable or had become unworkable, there was no basis to vary the Consent Order. Moreover, the Consent Order with respect to the division of matrimonial assets had been completely implemented.[note: 52] As such, the court did not have the power to revisit or reopen the order. On either ground, the Wife’s application to vary the Consent Order must fail.

Custody, care and control

61     I turn next to the Wife’s application to set aside/vary the Consent Order in relation to the custody, care and control of the child.

62     The Wife alleged that the Husband had engaged in parental alienation and attempted to exclude the Wife from the child’s life while falsely accusing the Wife of being an irresponsible parent.[note: 53] Following the divorce, the Husband repeatedly reneged on agreed terms regarding the Wife’s access to the child and the matrimonial flat. His communication and actions became increasingly uncooperative, hostile, and abusive, including denying access to the child on public holidays, changing visitation arrangements without consent, and preventing video calls.[note: 54]

63     The Wife alleged that the Husband had inflicted psychological harm on the child by coercing him to lie to the Wife about his whereabouts and activities. The Husband’s behavior, which included making unilateral decisions about the child’s schooling, health, and travel plans, significantly disrupted the co-parenting relationship and negatively impacted the child’s wellbeing.[note: 55] The Wife also accused the Husband of manipulating the child into referring to his new wife as “mummy” against the child’s will, using threats and punishment.[note: 56] The Husband had also fed him false information and used access as a means of control, resulting in the child experiencing panic and anxiety.[note: 57]

64     The Wife said that she had been the primary caregiver for the child since his birth and was deeply involved in his overall development, including academic preparation and various activities. Despite the Husband’s attempts to undermine the Wife’s role, the child had consistently expressed a desire to reside primarily with the Wife.[note: 58] The Wife requested for care and control of the child with the supervised access to the Husband.[note: 59]

65     The Husband contended that the Wife’s baseless and frivolous allegations of her being misled and misguided into letting him have care and control of the child was simply untrue and unsubstantiated.[note: 60] It was agreed between parties that the Husband would have care and control of the child as he had been the primary caregiver for the child since he was born.[note: 61] Since the Wife moved out from the matrimonial home in 2020, he had independently shouldered the responsibility of overseeing the child’s academic development and the child was thriving under his care.[note: 62]

66     The Husband said that despite the challenges of managing this responsibility single-handedly, he devoted his limited time with the child to providing guidance and encouragement. The child had consistently demonstrated improvement in academic performance and had earned numerous achievements. In a noteworthy accomplishment, the child secured a top three position in the class award for the first time in 2022. Even amidst the ongoing court proceedings since 2023, the Husband single-handedly persevered in maintaining the child’s academic excellence, resulting in him receiving the top three in the class award once again.[note: 63] The child had numerous other academic awards and achievements.[note: 64]

67     The Husband said that the Wife moved out almost four years ago to pursue her own “happiness” but after learning about the Husband’s remarriage, she initiated the current lawsuit to disrupt the hard-earned stability that the child and the Husband had been enjoying.[note: 65] The Husband contended that he had dutifully facilitated her stated access terms pursuant to the Consent Order but the Wife was belatedly demanding for more access timings after she learned of the Husband’s remarriage.[note: 66]

68     Section 128 of the Charter provides as follows:

The court may at any time vary or rescind any order for the custody, or the care and control, of a child on the application of any interested person, where it is satisfied that the order was based on any misrepresentation or mistake of fact or where there has been any material change in the circumstances.

69     For the same reasons explained earlier, I found no basis to set aside the Consent Order for the custody, care and control of the child. Be that as it may, the central issue was whether there was any basis to vary the Consent Order. In practical terms, any order relating to the custody, care and control of the child would be forward-looking, as it would not be possible to undo the past, unlike the division of matrimonial assets where the order could be undone ab initio, and the assets redivided.

70     The legal principles for the variation of a consent order on custody, care and control are markedly different from those applicable to the variation of a consent order on the division of matrimonial assets. This is why, as I had emphasized at [13] above, clarity of the submissions is important.

71     In DDN v DDO [2024] SGHC(A) 2 (at [16] & [17]), which concerned an application to vary the parties’ by-consent access orders, the Appellate Division (“AD”) held that the court will take a wider and more holistic approach to assess what constitutes a material change in circumstances for issues involving a child to ensure that there is sufficient flexibility to adjust orders relating to the child’s arrangements to suit the current circumstances. The AD quoted with approval, the following passage from AZB v AZC [2016] SGHCF 1 (at [32]):

Relationships are dynamic. A parent who is not emotionally close to a child at the time an access order is made may, through time, build a much closer relationship with the child subsequently. For example, a young three­ year old child may have been clingy to his mother at the time the court orders care and control to the mother and limited access to the father. As the child grows older and builds a closer relationship with his father, it may be in his welfare to encourage increased access when he is, say, five years old. The child may have outgrown the phase of high dependence on and dinginess to his mother. There may not have been any one particular identifiable event that marks a material change in circumstances between the time he was three and five years old, but because relationships are dynamic, circumstances may have sufficiently changed such that a variation is warranted for his welfare. Hence, the court ought not to read s 128 of the Women's Charter too narrowly, but should take both a principled and pragmatic approach to the determination of a material change in circumstances.

72     As noted in UBQ v UBR [2023] SGHC(A) 10 (“UBQ v UBR”) ([at [52]), the paramount consideration in a variation application is the welfare of the child.

73     From my review of the affidavits and the CER, I was satisfied that there had been a material change in circumstances for the purposes of the variation application. I noted that [T] was an emerging adolescent capable of forming an independent view. It was clear to me that [T] shared a close relationship with the Wife and desired to spend more time with her, compared to the current care arrangement.

74     As this was sufficient for invoking the court’s power to vary the Consent Order, I did not find it necessary or helpful to dwell into the parties’ allegations in my brief grounds to assign blame. Neither do I think it is necessary or helpful to do so now, bearing in mind the paramount consideration is the welfare of the child and not the past conduct of the parents: see UBQ v UBR (at [49]).

75     I found that both parents cared for the child and played their respective roles in supporting him. The Husband had provided the child a stable living environment and ensured that his daily needs were adequately met. The Husband was committed in supporting the child over academic matters and had contributed significantly to the child’s academic achievement while the Wife had also been intentional in engaging the child in a wide range of activities and was attuned to the child’s emotional wellbeing. However, while both parents cared for the child and played their respective roles in supporting him, they struggled with communication and co-parenting.

76     [T] was an intelligent child who had been doing well academically. Although he shared a close relationship with each parent, it was clear to me that he had been exposed to prolonged parental conflict and was torn between them.

77     The parties were agreeable to continue with the joint custody order. The main dispute centred on care with control. The Wife was seeking a reversal of care and control while the Husband wanted to continue having sole care and control of [T].

78     Section 125(2) of the Charter provides that:

In deciding in whose custody, or in whose care and control, a child should be placed, the paramount consideration is to be the welfare of the child and subject to this, the court is to have regard —

(a)    to the wishes of the parents of the child; and

(b)    to the wishes of the child, where he or she is of an age to express an independent opinion.

79     Given the Husband’s strength in providing the academic support, granting the Wife sole care and control would deprive the child of the support by the Husband. However, granting the Husband sole care and control would also deprive the child of the time and attention that he so desired from the Wife.

80     [T] was a mature individual and at an age where he was capable of greater independence and expressing an independent opinion. Given his close relationship with both parents as well as his desire to spend more time with the Wife, I found that a shared care and control arrangement where he would be able to receive the support and care from both parents would be beneficial for him.

81     In addition, the parents would benefit from continued counselling at FAM@FSC to work on their communication and co-parenting skills. [T] would also benefit from continued counselling at FAM@FSC to support him amidst the parental conflict.

82     According, I varied the orders relating to custody, care and control as follows:

(a)     Parents be granted joint custody of the child.

(b)     Parents be granted shared care and control of the child as follows:

(i)       Husband to have care and control of the child from Saturday 8 pm to Wednesday (before school).

(ii)       Wife to have care and control of the child from Wednesday (after school) to Saturday 8 pm.

(c)     Parents to share equally the school and public holidays.

Overseas Travel

(d)     The parents are at liberty to travel overseas with the child subject to giving the other party at least two months’ notice of the duration of travel, itinerary of travel, including flight details, accommodation address and emergency contact details. The notice period may be shortened by consent of the parties.

(e)     The Husband shall release the child’s passport to the Wife at least 2 weeks prior to the intended date of departure or earlier if the said passport is required for travel visa application. The Wife shall return the child’s passport to the Husband when returning the child to his care.

Mutual Agreement

(f)     Parties may vary the care arrangement by mutual agreement.

Make-up parenting time

(g)     Where a parent is denied parenting time with the child as a result of the unilateral decision of the other parent, the parent shall be entitled to make-up parenting time.

(h)     Parents should endeavour to resolve any such dispute amicably before making an application to the Court for make-up parenting time.

Counselling Support

(i)     Parents and child to continue to receive counselling support at FAM@FSC.

83     In my brief grounds, I had urged both parents to take positive steps to reduce their conflict, such as by exercising grace and flexibility in co-parenting and refraining from inflaming the situation. I reminded the parties that parental responsibility included supporting the child in having a close relationship with the other parent: see VPG v VPF [2021] SGHCF 18 (at [10]). The parties were advised to take heed of the following observations of Debbie Ong JAD in DDN v DDO (at [17]):

… the court expects parties to do their utmost to make the ordered arrangements work. This perspective is crucial to ensuring that “the child’s interests are not side-lined while his or her parents litigate over what they subjectively perceive to be their respective rights and entitlements” …

84     I emphasized that parental conflict was harmful to the child and made reference to the observations of the Court of Appeal in WKM v WKN [2024] SGCA 1 (at [40]). I also reiterated the following reminder in WBU v WBT [2023] SGHCF 3 (at [47]):

Parents must find the resolve to overcome the difficulties in co-parenting by a strong commitment to discharging their parental responsibility. Litigation has harmful effects on the child – materially, because the family loses in incurring litigation expenses, and psychologically, because conflict affects the whole family in ways not easily visible.

85     It is hence disappointing that despite the reminders and exhortations, the Wife had decided to appeal against the shared care and control order instead of doing her utmost to make the ordered arrangement work. While it is her prerogative as a litigant to do so, it would also mean that the litigation will be protracted. This would not be in the child’s welfare.

Maintenance for child

86     Finally, the Wife had also sought an order for the Husband to pay the Wife a reasonable amount of maintenance for the child. [note: 67]

87     The relevant provisions relating to the variation of maintenance for children are in ss 72 and 73 of the Charter. As noted by the Court of Appeal in AYM v AYL [2014] 4 SLR 559 (at [15]):

Section 73 provides that any agreement relating to maintenance may be varied where the court is “satisfied that it is reasonable and for the welfare of the child to do so”. … the provision is wide enough to encompass a material change in the circumstances of the parents as a basis for varying the maintenance for the child. Whether or not this should result in the maintenance actually being varied is of course a factual inquiry that depends on the circumstances of each case.

88     It is trite law that both parents have a duty to maintain the child. As regards the apportionment of maintenance, it is an established principle that the financial obligations of parents depend on their financial capacity. As noted in WBU v WBT [2023] SGHCF 3 (at [38]):

… financial capacity need not be rigidly ascertained by sole reference to income alone. Consistent with s 69(4)(b) of the Charter, the court should consider the parties’ “income, earning capacity (if any), property and other financial resources”, as well as significant liabilities and financial commitments…

89     In the present case, I found that the variation of the care and control arrangement would constitute a material change in circumstances. However, as noted above, whether this should result in the maintenance actually being varied is a factual inquiry that depends on the circumstances of the case. In the absence of supporting evidence to enable the court to determine the reasonable expenses of the child and the financial capacities of the parents, there was no proper basis for me to decide whether and how the existing maintenance order should be varied.

90     In the circumstances, I made no order on the Wife’s application to vary the existing maintenance order for the child. This was without prejudice to the Wife filing a fresh application with supporting evidence.

Costs

91     As I was of the view that it was important to help parties heal and move on, I made no order as to costs: see BNH v BNI [2013] 283 (at [50]) and USC v USD [2021] SGHCF 4 (at [9]).
