html:
XIO v XIP

XIO v XIP
[2025] SGFC 18

Case Number:SS 983 of 2024
Decision Date:13 February 2025
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Lynette Yap
Counsel Name(s): Ho Shiao Hong and Yap Tong Hitomi (M/s Quahe Woo & Palmer LLC) for the Complainant; Wong Yong Zhi Jonathan, Berlin Soh Su Ming and Alicia Jiang Shu Yee (M/s Bayfront Law LLC) for the Respondent
Parties: XIO — XIP

Family Law – Family Violence

13 February 2025

Judgment reserved

District Judge Lynette Yap:

Introduction

1       This was the Mother’s application for a Personal Protection Order (“PPO”) against the Father for herself and their three young children, [A] who is 4 years old and twins [B] and [C], who are 1 year old. The Mother also applied for a Domestic Exclusion Order (“DEO”) against the Father in respect of the entire matrimonial flat where they resided.

2       I heard the trial over 4 days. The Mother testified and called 5 witnesses - her father, 3 domestic helpers and her aunt. The Father testified and called 4 witnesses - his mother, his aunt and 2 friends.

3       Upon conclusion of the trial, I directed parties to file written submissions and reserved my judgment. This is my decision.

The Law

4       The Court will only grant a PPO if the following two requirements are fulfilled:

(a)     Family violence must have been committed, or there is a likelihood that family violence will be committed; and

(b)     The PPO must be necessary for the protection of the family member.

5       The evidential standard of proof to be applied in PPO proceedings is that of the civil standard of “on a balance of probabilities”, and not the more stringent “beyond reasonable doubt” criminal standard of proof. However, the protection conferred by a PPO carries with it criminal sanctions. Pursuant to s 65(8) of the Women’s Charter 1961 (the “Charter”), a person who wilfully contravenes a PPO is guilty of a criminal offence and will be liable on conviction to a fine not exceeding $2,000 or to imprisonment for a term not exceeding six months or to both. In addition, a police officer who has reason to suspect that a person has wilfully contravened a PPO may arrest the person without a warrant[note: 1]. Given these criminal consequences, a PPO will not be lightly ordered[note: 2].

6       As to what constitutes family violence, this is set out in s 64 of the Charter:

“family violence” means the commission of any of the following acts:

(a)    Wilfully or knowingly placing or attempting to place, a family member in fear of hurt;

(b)    Causing hurt to a family member by such act which is known or ought to have been known would result in hurt;

(c)    Wrongfully confining or restraining a family member against his or her will;

(d)    Causing continual harassment with intent to cause or knowing that it is likely to cause anguish to a family member,

but does not include any force lawfully used in self-defence, or by way of correction towards a child below 21 years of age.

Allegations of Family Violence

7       The Mother’s case is that the Father had committed family violence against herself and the 3 children under all 4 limbs (a) to (d) in s 64 of the Charter.

8       In her opening statement, the Mother asserted that the Father had an unstable mental state, a violent disposition and was quick to anger by nature, and that even before the marriage, he had at times exhibited low mood, low self-esteem and was easily agitated. She also stated that he repeatedly acted in a verbally abusive, threatening and hostile matter towards her, especially from 2020 onwards. She asserted that over time, his unpredictable mood and frequent outbursts of anger towards her caused her to feel constant background anxiety when he was around her. She further asserted that after their eldest and then the twins were born, the Father’s abusive and violent behaviour also affected them[note: 3].

9       In deciding this case, I considered whether family violence has been committed by the Father under the different limbs (a) to (d) in s 64 of the Charter.

(a) Wilfully or knowingly placing or attempting to place, a family member in fear of hurt

10     Under limb (a), it is important to bear in mind that the acts of the perpetrator will not constitute family violence unless he acted with an intention to place the victim in fear of hurt, or with the knowledge that the victim would, by the acts, be placed in fear of hurt. These are “subjective” states of mind in that the perpetrator must have the requisite intention or knowledge[note: 4]. For example, a perpetrator might express his frustration in the presence of the victim. This act alone, without the requisite intention or knowledge, will not constitute family violence even though such expression may be inappropriate and ill-advised.

11     In UNQ v UNR [2020] SGHCF 21 (“UNQ”), a mother applied for a PPO on behalf of her children against their father. She alleged, among other things, that the father had thrown things around the house including a metal coffee mug. The father denied these allegations. The Family Division of the High Court held that the act of the father in throwing a metal coffee mug could amount to family violence if there was evidence that the children were standing in the direction where the mug was flung. The Court found that the act of the father, even if true, was at worst inappropriate but did not constitute family violence.

12     I will now consider the incidents relied on by the Mother to mount her case that the Father had committed family violence by wilfully or knowingly placing or attempting to place her and the children in fear of hurt:

1. Incident in or around August 2016

13     The Mother alleged that on or around 9 August 2016, shortly after parties were married, parties had an argument and the Father shouted at the Mother and tried to pin her to a cabinet. The Mother alleged that he caused her hurt and pain and bruised the back of her hand[note: 5].

14     The Father’s version was that the Mother had raised her hand and tried to assault him, causing him to push her arm away out of reflex to ensure that the Mother would not hit him and as a result he came into contact with her arm[note: 6].

15     As this was the Mother’s application, she had to prove that the incident occurred in the manner she alleged. I find that the Father’s account of the incident was more credible than that of the Mother’s and I accepted the Father’s evidence given both in his affidavit and tested during cross-examination that it was the Mother who had tried to assault him[note: 7]. I also note that there was no contemporaneous evidence such as a police report or a medical memo that the incident occurred in the manner alleged by the Mother.

16     Furthermore, this was an isolated incident that occurred back in 2016. No other incidents are alleged to have occurred between 2016 and 2020, and the parties continued to live together, with no evidence that the Mother had been put in fear of hurt as a result of this incident.

17     On balance, I do not accept that the Mother has proven that Father had wilfully or knowingly placed or attempted to place the Mother in fear of hurt.

2. Incident in 2020 during the Mother’s pregnancy with [A]

18     The Mother next relied on an incident that occurred four years later in 2020, when she became pregnant with [A]. The Mother explained that [A] was conceived by way of intra-uterine insemination (“IUI”) and she underwent multiple IUI attempts in 2019 involving numerous hormonal injections over multiple months[note: 8].

19     The Mother stated that she suffered from frequent bleeding and was hospitalised due to threatened abortion in her first trimester and threatened premature labour in her second and third trimesters. It is the Mother’s case that the Father had frequent outbursts and would yell at her when he visited her at the hospital. He had also said that it would be better for her to have a miscarriage. She stated that as she “feared for the safety of (herself) and the yet-unborn (child)” she moved into her parents’ home to live with them after she was discharged from the hospital. She also continued to stay with her parents after she was discharged a second time from a government hospital in July 2020.

20     The Father denied her allegations. He stated in his affidavit that the Mother was in and out of hospitals frequently due to her difficult pregnancy. He denied telling the Mother that it would be better for her to have a miscarriage and stated instead that he had told her that in the event of a difficult birth, he would much rather she live instead of the unborn child. He stated that the parties had disagreements on whether the Mother should transfer from a private hospital to a government hospital. He further stated that the Mother needed 2 daily injections at a clinic near her parents’ home and decided it would be best for her to live at her parents’ home.

21     During cross-examination, while the Mother maintained that she moved into her parents’ place because she feared for the safety of herself and the unborn child in April 2020 after her first discharge from hospital, she was unable to identify any specific incident of alleged violence committed by the Father before April 2020 other than the incident in August 2016. On the stand, she conceded that to the best of her memory she was unable to recall[note: 9]. When probed further if she could identify any other incident of violence stated in her affidavit before April 2020, she did not refer to any specific incident but instead referred to paragraph 51 of her affidavit where she had stated generally that throughout her pregnancy, the Father would have frequent violent outbursts and shouted at her.

22     The Father’s alleged outbursts and shouts at the Mother will not constitute family violence unless he had the requisite “subjective” state of mind, in the sense that he must have had the intention or knowledge to place or attempt to place her in fear of hurt. The authorities are clear that a mere expression of frustration by the perpetrator in the presence of the victim made without any such intention or knowledge will not in itself constitute family violence even if such expression may be inappropriate and ill advised[note: 10]. On the whole, I do not accept that the Father’ outbursts and shouts, even if accepted, would amount to him wilfully or knowingly placing or attempting to place the Mother in fear or hurt. I will also add that the documents relied on by the Mother did not assist her in proving that she had been in fear of hurt due to the father’s actions. She had exhibited an inpatient discharge summary from a private hospital dated 13 April 2020, stating that she had been admitted since 20 February 2020 for “threatened abortion”, an inpatient discharge summary from SGH dated 14 July 2020 where she had been diagnosed for “threatened premature labor” and another inpatient discharge summary dated 2 August 2020 where she had been diagnosed with “premature or threatened labor”[note: 11]. She further exhibited a memo from the Women’s Mental Wellness, KKH dated 28 August 2020 that stated that her stress levels were very high[note: 12]. None of these documents prove that the Mother’s medical conditions were caused by any specific act of family violence committed by the Father. They certainly did not show that the Father had wilfully or knowingly placed or attempted to place the Mother in fear of hurt.

3. Incident in or around July 2020

23     The Mother stated in her affidavit that the Father had come to her parents’ house where she was living after her second discharge from hospital to visit her. Both of them got into a disagreement on the preparations for the baby’s arrival and the Father shouted at her using vulgarities. The Mother alleged that he hit the wall and the bedframe.

24     The Father’s version was that the Mother had given him a number of tasks to prepare for the arrival of the baby. He had not completed all of them and the Mother made remarks such as “you’re not ready to be a father?” and “how can I trust you if you can’t even get these simple things done”. He stated that he swore in frustration at the situation.

25     In my judgment, the Father’s alleged act of shouting at the Mother with vulgarities and his actions of hitting the wall and the bedframe, even if true, was at worst inappropriate and ill-advised. There was no evidence to show that the Father had acted with an intention to place or attempted to place the Mother in fear of hurt, or with the knowledge that the Mother would by the acts be placed in fear of hurt, for example if there was evidence that he had aimed his punch in the direction of the Mother and had hit the wall and the bedframe instead. I am unable to conclude that the Father’s actions constituted family violence.

4. Incident on or around 23 August 2020

26     The next incident cited by the Mother occurred when the Mother and her parents went to the parties’ matrimonial flat where the Father was living alone to pick up some clothes. Prior to that, the Mother’s parents had ordered a baby’s cot to be shipped there and the Mother had asked the Father to assemble the cot as the Mother had hoped the both of them could live together after the baby was born. While there, the Mother found that the place was in a mess and the baby’s cot was only partially assembled and a disagreement arose between the parties. The Mother alleged that the Father shouted that she was accusing him of being a bad father, even though she had not done so, and that he yelled at her and her father to get out of the house and shouted vulgarities. He also threw the baby’s items onto the floor and punched the wall with his fists.

27     The Father’s version was that he was living alone in the matrimonial flat. The Mother and her parents arrived and started berating him and finding fault with him and the state that the house was in for at least an hour before he raised his voice and told them to stop shouting at him. He denied that he had touched anyone or made any gesture that he would hit or use physical violence against anyone.

28     On the facts, I do not find that the Father had acted with an intention to place or attempted to place the Mother in fear of hurt, or with the knowledge that the Mother would be placed in fear of hurt. The Mother’s allegation was that he had thrown the baby’s items onto the floor and punched the wall with his fists. It was not her case that he had thrown the baby’s items at her or that he had aimed a punch in her direction and hit the wall instead. At all times, the Mother was free to leave the matrimonial flat and disengage from the disagreement if she had truly been in fear of hurt. Furthermore, even if the Mother had indeed been in fear of hurt, I was unable to conclude from the evidence that the Father had the requisite mental element.

5. Incident in or around December 2020 after [A] was born

29     After [A] was born, the Father moved into the home of the Mother’s parents. The Mother stated that she wanted to keep the family intact and was reassured that her parents would be physically present if things got out of hand. The Mother stated that the Father appeared to be unhealthily obsessed with [A], and “whenever someone (like me) tended to [A], (he) would get disproportionately upset…”

30     The Father denied that he had behaved in a threatening manner. He explained that his requests for permission to spend time with [A] were met with unjustified ridicule, scolding and doubts from the Mother and her parents. He felt that this was humiliating and even when he requested to take [A] downstairs around the block to walk, this request would be rejected or they would say he needed to be accompanied by the helper.

31     In or around December 2020, the Mother alleged that she was carrying [A] in the bedroom when her parents were out. The Father came into the room and asked to take [A]. She declined as [A] was asleep and she did not want him to be disturbed. The Father then shouted at her and accused her of denying him access to [A]. He tried to snatch [A] from her and she retreated into a corner of the room to avoid the Father. She tried to get past the Father to leave the room but he came very close to her with his arms outstretched towards her and [A]. Her fear was exacerbated because she had claustrophobia which she had told the Father about before.

32     The Mother stated that she eventually managed to get past the Father and leave the room with [A]. She went quickly to her parents’ room where her phone was and called her father. By then, the Father had left and she returned to the bedroom with [A] and locked the door[note: 13].

33     The Mother’s father gave evidence that he and his wife rushed home upon receiving the Mother’s call. He asked the Mother if the Father had beat her, and the Mother responded that she was afraid that the Father would have hurt her physically if her parents had not come home as soon as they could.

34     The Father denied these allegations. He stated that the Mother was in a bad mood that day as he had accidentally left the fridge door open in the morning. This upset the Mother as she said that the breast milk could spoil and could kill [A] if he drank it. She commented that the Father was a danger to the baby and that the baby he would die in his care. The Father stated he had apologised profusely to the Mother.

35     The Father stated that he had asked the Mother if he could spend time with [A]. Three hours after the Mother had been in the room with [A], he went in to check in on them. He denied that he had tried to snatch [A] from the Mother. He explained that when the Mother started accusing him, he did not want to leave the room for fear that the Mother was suffering from post-partum depression. His version was that the Mother pushed and punched him and dug her fingers into his arms before she called her parents[note: 14]. He exhibited undated photographs of injuries he claimed to have sustained on his arm. He also exhibited contemporaneous WhatsApp messages he had exchanged with his friend that day to support his version of what had transpired[note: 15].

36     Since this is the Mother’s application for a PPO, she has to prove that the Father had wilfully or knowingly placed or attempted to place her in fear of hurt. I have considered the evidence available before the Court and I am unable to find that the Mother was in fear of hurt. It was her case that the Father wanted access to [A], but she refused as she did not want [A] to be disturbed from his sleep. What ensued thereafter was a disagreement between parties as to who would get to spend time with [A]. Even on the Mother’s own evidence, there are no allegations of actions by the Father that could be construed to be placing or attempting to place her in fear of hurt. I did not find that there was sufficient evidence to show that the Father had acted with the necessary intention to place or attempt to place the Mother in fear of hurt, or with the knowledge that the Mother would by his acts be placed in fear of hurt. His actions merely showed that he wanted access to [A] which the Mother was refusing to give.

6. Incident on or around 12 February 2021

37     The Mother stated that during Chinese New Year, the parties were at the home of the Mother’s relative. The parties had planned to go for dinner at the Father’s parents’ home after that. The Mother had told the Father before they went to her relative’s home that they would only be able to leave for his parents’ home after she had finished breastfeeding [A] to avoid disrupting his feeding schedule. The Mother stated that at that time, the Father had agreed[note: 16].

38     The Mother stated that while she was breastfeeding [A] in her cousin’s room, the Father came into the room and demanded that they leave for his parents’ home as they were late for dinner. She reminded him that they had agreed to leave only after [A] had finished breastfeeding. The Father began to shout and demand they leave immediately. She was shaken and in fear and called her parents over the phone. Her father came into the room and asked what happened. The Mother explained that she needed more time to feed [A], and her father told the Father to call his parents to explain that they would be late and the Father stomped out of the room.

39     The Mother’s father gave evidence in his affidavit that he also left the room after the Father left and when they were outside the room, he told the Father to be more reasonable to give the Mother more time to tend to [A]’s needs. The Father became angry and started to raise his voice and banged his fists on the wall and furniture[note: 17].

40     After the Mother finished breastfeeding [A], parties left the relative’s place and the Mother alleged that the Father drove in a dangerous manner to his parents’ place, weaving in and out of traffic even though the Mother and [A] were in the car, and she feared for their safety.

41     The Father’s account was that parties were almost 2 hours late for dinner with his parents. He was frustrated that the Mother did not want to leave her relative’s home. He stated that he had hit a soft cushion on the chair but he denied punching the furniture or the wall of the relative’s home.

42     Taking the Mother’s case at its highest, even if the Father had punched the furniture and the wall (which was denied by the Father), that could not amount to wilfully or knowingly placing the Mother in fear of hurt since it was not done in her presence but only after the Father had left the room she was in.

43     In any event, I do not accept that the Father had acted with an intention to place or attempt to place the Mother in fear of hurt, or with the knowledge that the Mother would be placed in fear of hurt. I will also add that despite the alleged concerns of the Mother’s relatives, all of them, including her father, had allowed the Mother to leave with the Father for his parents’ place. The Mother’s relative also confirmed at the trial that she called the Mother to ask if she had reached the Father’s parents’ place safely and the Mother confirmed this.

7. Incident in or around May 2021

44     It is the Mother’s case that after a couples counselling session, the Father shouted at her during the car ride back. The impact of him shouting at her was exacerbated by her claustrophobia as she was trapped in the same space as the Father who was driving the car.

45     The Father’s case was that the Mother started accusing the Father of not informing the counsellors about an incident that took place on 8 May 2021 and the parties had a disagreement where he was upset with the Mother. The Mother requested to be dropped off near her home and he dropped her off.

46     On the facts, I found that a disagreement arose between the parties while the Father was driving the vehicle and this led to the Mother being dropped off the car at her request. I do not find that there was any evidence to support the Mother’s contention that she had been in fear of hurt or that the Father had wilfully or knowingly placed or attempted to place the Mother in fear of hurt.

8. Incident on or around 6 June 2021

47     The Mother claims that the Father had shouted at her for about an hour at her parents’ home and harassed her to move out of her parents’ home. Her parents tried to intervene and the Father shouted at them to get out of the room and continued shouting at the Mother inside the room. The Father then went on a hunger strike and refused to eat, knowing that this would cause the Mother anguish.

48     The Father stated that he was merely discussing the matter of moving out of the home of the Mother’s parents. He denied going on a hunger strike to cause distress to the Mother and explained it was because he lost his appetite.

49     In my judgement, even if the shouting and the alleged hunger strike had occurred, I do not find that there was sufficient evidence to show that the Mother had been in fear of hurt. In addition, there was no evidence to show that the Father had wilfully or knowingly placed or attempted to place the Mother in fear of hurt. The Mother was clearly free to refuse to move out of her parents’ home without any consequences, which was in fact what happened on 8 June 2021, when the Mother did not join the Father when he moved out of the home of the Mother’s parents.

9. Incident in or around August 2022

50     More than a year later, in or around August 2022, the Mother stated that after parties attended a marriage workshop, the Father shouted at her in public for not being a good wife and called her a “bad wife” and a “bully”. She was afraid of being near him and walked away. Parties eventually went home separately.

51     The Father explained that the Mother had raised an unresolved issue from the marriage workshop, insisted that she had “reached the end of the road for this marriage” and it was she who started raising her voice at the Father.

52     I do not find that the Mother was in fear of hurt. There was no evidence of any physical threat. The Mother’s own evidence was that she “walked away from (the Father) to distance (herself) from (his) shouting and public humiliation of (her)” and proceeded to “(take) the MRT back to” her parents’ home. I accept the Father’s submissions that at all material times, she was free to and did in fact disengage and leave the Father by taking public transportation to her parents’ home. I did not accept that the Mother had shown that the Father had wilfully or knowingly placed her in fear of hurt.

10. Incidents from 7 June 2023 to 12 June 2023 while parties were overseas

53     The parties went overseas in June 2023. The trip comprised 8 people: the couple, [A], the helper, the Mother’s parents, a pastor who was also a friend of the Mother’s father and the pastor’s wife. The Mother’s brother had committed suicide overseas a few years before that and the family were there to commemorate his death anniversary.

54     By this time, the Mother was expecting twins. [A] was then 2 years and 9 months old. The Mother asserted that during the trip, the Father would shout at [A] whenever he was “tired or emotionally dysregulated”[note: 18]. She listed the following 4 incidents:

7 June 2023

55     The Mother alleged that on 7 June 2023, while parties were in a maxicab to their Airbnb accommodation, [A] was tired as he had not slept well on the plane and was being fussy in the maxicab. The Father shouted at him to stop and threatened to beat [A]. He also threatened to leave [A] in the maxicab.

9 June 2023

56     The Mother alleged that on 9 June 2023, parties were at a playground when [A] became hungry and tired. Parties walked to a shopping street to have lunch and [A] was behaving in an unsettled manner and crying. The Mother asked the Father to carry [A] so that she could order food, but [A] did not want the Father to carry him and made a fuss. The Father pinned [A’s] arms down and forcefully carried him away from the café. The Mother asked the helper [E] to go check on [A] and after a while, [E] returned and said she was unable to make [A] calm down. The Mother left the cafe to look for the Father and [A]. She could hear [A] crying and the Father yelling and threatening to abandon [A] in the shopping street.

10 June 2023

57     The Mother alleged that on 10 June 2023, all 9 of them were in a maxicab, heading to a columbarium outside the city. [A] was tired and started to cry. The Father shouted at [A] saying that he would have the maxicab driver take him away.

11 June 2023

58     The Mother alleged that on 11 June 2023, as their flight back to Singapore was very late, around 11 pm, [A] was tired as it was past his bedtime. He was also restless and hungry and started to run around the airport and at times, he would get upset and cry and yell. In response, the Father shouted at [A] and threatened to leave him behind.

My findings

59     The Mother’s own evidence, at its highest, is that the Father shouted and threatened [A] when [A] was tired, fussy or crying while they were overseas. In my view, while the Father may not have acted in the most exemplary manner when dealing with a tired toddler who was crying and fussing on an overseas trip, I do not accept that the Father had wilfully or knowingly placed or attempted to place [A] in fear of hurt.

11. Incident in or around August 2023

60     The Mother gave birth to twins, [B] and [C] on 14 August 2023. She alleged that shortly after she returned to her parents’ home, the Father shouted at her and demanded that she pack up all her things to move to their own matrimonial flat. In her closing submissions, she submitted that she was put in fear and felt compelled to move to their matrimonial flat[note: 19].

61     The Father’s evidence is that he spoke firmly to the Mother and the Mother eventually agreed to move to their matrimonial flat.

62     I found it hard to accept the Mother’s submissions that she was in fear of hurt, nor was there any evidence of threat beyond that of a quarrel. This contradicted her own evidence in her affidavit that she moved to live with the Father as she was “hoping to give the marriage another chance for the children’s sake, especially the twins”. She had also stated that she “had no choice but to move into the (residence) with (the Father) as there was no space at her (parents’ flat) for the twins”[note: 20]. I rejected her claim that she was in fear of hurt.

12. Incident in or around September 2023

63     The helper, [E], engaged to care for [A], stated in her affidavit that sometime in September 2023, she was at the matrimonial flat with [A] as it was a weekend. [E] alleged that [A] woke up during his afternoon nap and cried for the Mother. The Father came into the room and yelled at [A] to stop crying, but [A] did not stop crying. The Father then took a bamboo cane and beat [A] multiple times on the leg, causing him to scream, cry even more and choke on his own saliva. [A] had difficulty breathing and his nose started to bleed. [E]’s evidence was that she pleaded with the Father to stop beating [A] and the Mother rushed into the room because she heard [A] scream loudly. It was only then that the Father stopped beating [A][note: 21].

64     The Father disputed this, stating that [A] had been crying non-stop for a good half an hour. He recalled that the Mother had been increasingly telling him to be stricter and to discipline [A] and the Mother herself had also just started using a cane to discipline [A]. He carried [A] in an attempt to soothe him, but [A] would not stop crying and [A] instead started hitting the Father. The Father told [A] to stop but he would not listen and this continued for at least another half an hour. The Father then took the cane and tried to apply the Mother’s method of physical discipline. He denied that [E] had pleaded with him to stop beating [A][note: 22].

65     I accept the Father’s account of the incident. Apart from [E], no other witnesses, including the Mother herself, gave evidence on this incident in their affidavits. According to [E], [A] was having difficulty breathing and his nose started to bleed, and the Mother rushed into the room because she heard [A] scream loudly and it was only then that the Father stopped beating [A]. Yet despite the severity of the alleged beating, breathing difficulty and nosebleed, there is no evidence that medical attention was sought for [A]. I also note that the Mother herself has given no evidence at all regarding this incident in her affidavits or on the stand, if it had indeed transpired as [E] described, despite citing numerous other incidents less serious in nature throughout her case. On balance, I preferred the Father’s account of what occurred.

13. Incident in or around October or November 2023

66     This incident was also only mentioned in [E]’s affidavit. According to [E], the Father, [A] and herself were on the 10th floor lift lobby of the matrimonial flat as the Mother was breastfeeding [B] and they wanted to keep [A] away from the Mother. [A] was crying because he wanted to be with the Mother. [E] alleged that the Father shouted at [A] and threatened to leave [A] on the 17th floor of the block, which was the highest floor of the block. [E]’s evidence was that [A] cried, then suddenly became unnaturally quiet. [E] alleged that after this incident, [A] became very afraid of entering the lift of the matrimonial flat, saying, “I don’t want, I don’t want. Don’t press the 17th floor button”[note: 23].

67     The Father disputed [E]’s account entirely. He stated that he was unable to recall such an incident as he had never threatened to leave [A] at the highest floor of the block. He asserted that it was the helpers and the Mother’s parents who used this threat when [A] lived with them on weekdays. He did not know if anyone had actually taken [A] to the top floor of the matrimonial flat before. He stated that [E] herself had also jokingly threatened to take [A] to the top floor if he misbehaved.

68     I preferred the Father’s evidence over [E]’s. I found it difficult to accept that a toddler would have the concept of the 17th floor as the highest floor and become very afraid of entering the lift of the matrimonial flat, to the extent that he would say specifically “Don’t press the 17th floor button” after only 1 incident when he was threatened on the 10th floor lift lobby, which was on a completely different floor.

69     In any event, even if the Father had threatened to leave [A] on the 17th floor of the block (which I did not accept), I do not see how this caused [A] to be in fear of hurt. I also do not see how the Father could be said to have wilfully or knowingly placed or attempted to place [A] in fear of hurt.

14. Incident on or around 17 March 2024

70     The Mother exhibited an audio recording of the Father shouting at [A] in the car and threatening to beat him[note: 24].

71     The Father explained that this recording was taken 3 weeks after the Father stopped talking with the Mother and her parents. He wanted to go to church that day as he needed to pray. Before parties got into the car, [A] started claiming that he did not want the Father to go to church with them. The Father ignored this. Inside the car, [A] sat on the Mother’s lap in the front passenger seat and was holding a portable fan. [A] started hitting the Father with the portable fan while saying, “I don’t like dada, I hate dada”. The Father told him to stop being rude. [A] did not stop even after he was told by the Father to stop thrice. The Father took the portable fan away from [A] and told him that he was going to discipline him. The Father maintained that he did not hit [A][note: 25].

72     The transcript of the recording showed that after the Father told [A] to “stop beating people already”, [A] stated “Later I beat you Dada. I beat”. When the Father stated, “You want me to take out the cane?”, [A’s] response was “Go Away”. In fact, [A] tells the Father 3 times to “Go away”. On the whole, I did not find that the Father’s actions were anything out of the ordinary in the normal disciplining of a child. I reject the proposition that family violence had been committed.

15. Incident on or around 4 May 2024

73     The Mother stated that [A] was with them at the matrimonial flat as it was a weekend. The Mother suspected that the Father had contracted Covid-19 and asked him not to go too close to the twins especially since they were born premature, making them more susceptible to illness than their peers.

74     [A] was helping to feed [C] in the playpen but the Father wanted to feed [C] instead. The Mother reminded the Father not to go too near [C] as the Father was unwell. The Father shouted at the Mother that she was preventing him from having access to [C]. He also shouted at [A], saying it was unfair that [A] who was sick could feed [C], when he could not. The Mother stated that [A] then cowered in fear.

75     Subsequently, the Mother, [A] and [E] (the helper who looked after [A]) went out. When they returned around 4 pm, the Father approached [A] who did not want to speak to the Father. The Father got angry and started to scold [A] for having “shit values” and that he was brought up by the Mother and her parents to be hateful. The Mother asked [A] and the helper to go up to [A]’s room to be away from the Father. She then carried [B] to the kitchen to put some distance between herself and the Father. The Father continued to yell at her and accused her of telling everyone that he was crazy and not a good father. He berated her for not being a good mother. She started to video record him.

76     The Father submitted that the video recording submitted by the Mother showed that he walked away from the Mother right after stating his points.

77     I do not accept that the Mother or [A] was in fear of hurt. There is no evidence that the Father threatened any act of physical violence. At all times, the Mother was fully in the position to intervene and disengage, as when she told [A] and the helper to go up to [A]’s room. She was also able to go out with [A] in the afternoon. She also went freely to the kitchen to put some distance between herself and the Father. I also did not find that the Father had the necessary intent to place or attempt to place her or [A] in fear of hurt. He walked away from the Mother after stating his points.

16. Incident on or around 9 May 2024

78     The Mother’s version was that her mother was at the matrimonial flat that afternoon to care for the twins and her mother had a scuffle with the Father’s mother who had also come by to the matrimonial flat. The Mother rushed home from work and then texted their marriage counsellor [Y]. Subsequently, the Mother heard objects being thrown on the floor and the Father screaming expletives. He also slammed the door of the study room. She went upstairs to investigate and heard the Father shouting while he was talking with [Y] over the phone. The Mother overheard that he was shouting “cunt”, “motherfucker”, “hateful” and “go to hell”. She deduced that [Y] must have called the Father after receiving the Mother’s text message. She captured an audio recording of the Father taken from the outside the study room shouting while he was on the phone with [Y].

79     Shortly after, the Father opened the door of the study room and saw the Mother standing in the hallway of the second floor. He came very close to her, pointed threateningly at her and shouted at her. She started recording his actions.

80     The helper who looked after [B] came up the stairs and took [B] whom the Mother was carrying. The Father turned away from the Mother and walked away and the Mother took the chance to go to the first floor. She then called the police and while waiting for the police to arrive, locked herself, the twins [B] and [C] and the 2 helpers who looked after [B] and [C] in a room. The Mother submitted a copy of a memo from her psychologist dated 10 May 2024, whom she had been visiting since August 2017 for “mental health support due to stress and emotional trauma[note: 26].

81     The Father submitted that the recordings did not show that he had sworn at the Mother or that he had directed his outburst at her. He submitted that the Mother’s psychologist was not called as a witness. More importantly, the psychologist’s memo dated 10 May 2024 did not state that family violence had been committed[note: 27].

82     On the whole, even if the events had occurred as alleged by the Mother, I do not accept that the Mother had been in fear of hurt. If she was indeed fearful after hearing objects being thrown on the floor and the Father screaming expletives and slamming the door of the study room on the second floor, it is unlikely that she would choose to walk upstairs to investigate and try to hear and audio record what the Father was saying in his conversation with [Y] behind closed doors. I accepted the Father’s submission that there was also no evidence that he had wilfully or knowingly placed the Mother or the children in fear of hurt. He was expressing his frustrations in the study room with the door closed when he was speaking to [Y] over the phone. The audio recording also showed that the Father was addressing [Y] and saying that “he did not want to fight (the Mother)” and that he “will not beat her and he will not touch her”[note: 28]. I also note that the Mother had admitted at the trial that she had actually not seen the psychologist whose memo she exhibited dated 10 May 2024 on both the material dates of 9 and 10 May 2024. Her psychologist had also not met the Father as well[note: 29]. There was also nothing in the memo that supported the Mother’s contention that family violence had been committed on 9 May 2024.

17. Incident on or around 22 and 23 May 2024

83     The Mother alleged that sometime in the middle of the night, [C] woke up and began to cry. Both the Mother and the Father went downstairs where the helper who looked after her was patting her to sleep. The Father kept asking the helper to pass [C] to him but the helper did not want to. The Father accused the Mother of instructing the helper not to hand [C] to him. He then stomped away. The Mother went back upstairs to her room to sleep.

84     The Mother alleged that shortly after, she was lying in bed when the Father barged in and shouted at her and accused her of preventing him from having access to [C]. She hid under her blanket and remained silent. After shouting for a while, the Father left the room. She then locked the door to prevent him from entering.

85     The next morning, while the Mother was getting ready for work, the Father continued to accuse her of preventing him from carrying the twins. She called the police as she was concerned the Father’s behaviour would escalate. The Father shouted at her and she took her phone to record him in an attempt to deter his abusive behaviour. Instead, the Father got in her face, taunted her for recording him, grabbed her arm and shook her violently.

86     Before the Mother left the house, she wanted to carry [B] for a while to say goodbye. The Father who was sitting in [B]’s playpen and carrying [B] refused and asked the Mother why she needed to carry [B] and stop the Father from spending time with [B]. She told him she was not stopping the Father from spending time with [B] and she just wanted to carry [B] for a short while. She then entered the playpen to take [B] out and carried him while the Father followed her around the residence and accused him of not letting him have [B].

87     After the Mother put [B] down and left him in his helper’s care, she went to the main door of the residence to leave for work when the Father berated her from a distance, again accusing her of not letting him have [B]. He then approached her threateningly while she was at the main door. The Mother said she feared for her safety and went towards a “safety room” where the helpers of [B] and [C] were and tried to close the door. However, the Father stuck his arm into the opening of the doorway and shouted that the Mother could not lock herself, the 2 helpers and the twins in the room as that would deny him access to the twins. He then struck the door of the room with his arm that was in the opening of the door multiple times and threatened her that he would tell the police that she had hurt him.

88     After a while, the Father removed his arm from the door and the helper who looked after [C] carried her out as [C] needed to feed. At the same time, the police arrived.

89     The Father disputed the Mother’s allegation that he had grabbed her arm and shook her while she was trying to film him. He also disputed that the room was a “safety room” and alleged that the Mother would always take the children into the room when she wanted to deny him access to them.

90     After considering the evidence, I did not find that family violence had been committed. Despite having the CCTVs in the matrimonial flat, and having her phone recording on, the only recording submitted by the Mother of the Father allegedly shaking her violently was only 5 seconds long and did not show the Father shaking her violently[note: 30]. The recording also showed that the Father did not raise his voice at her. In any event, I will add that even if the Father had grabbed the Mother’s arm and shook her, this action did not cause the Mother to be in fear of hurt. The Mother’s own evidence was that shortly after this, she chose to go to the playpen where the Father was sitting in and carrying [B] in as she wanted to spend time with [B]. If she was truly in fear of hurt, it was inexplicable that she would dare to approach the Father who was sitting in the playpen with [B].

91     For completeness, I will add that the Mother’s evidence was that even before the police arrived, the Father had removed his arm from the door and the helper who looked after [C] carried her out as [C] needed to feed. Again, if the Mother was truly in fear of being hurt, it really did not make sense that she would allow [C] and the helper to leave as surely [C]’s need to be fed could wait till the police arrived.

18. Incident on 25 May 2024

92     The Mother alleged that on 25 May 2024, a Saturday, the Father wanted to take [C] out to a picnic with his friends. The Mother did not agree that he should take [C] out on his own without the support of the helpers. The Father threatened to take [C] out of the residence and to the picnic and also threatened to stop her from taking [A] out for his activities if she did not allow the Father to bring [C] out for the picnic.

93     The Mother was afraid that the Father would go through with his threat of stopping her from taking [A] out and called the police for assistance. The Father learnt that she had called the police and followed the Mother from the living room to the main door where she was waiting for the police. He accused her of denying him access to the children and said that if she did not let him have the children, he would not allow her to have the children and threatened to have Child Protection Services take the children away. When the policemen arrived, they spent a substantial amount of time in the Father’s room. Subsequently one of the policemen called the Mother to the room and spoke to both of them together. The Mother made a police report regarding the incident. As she was afraid for both her and the children’s safety, she asked her mother to stay with them until the following Monday 27 May 2024 when she applied for PPOs for herself and the 3 children as well as a DEO in respect of the entire matrimonial residence. On 27 May 2024, an Expedited Order was granted to restrain the Father from committing family violence against the Mother and [A].

94     The Father denied the Mother’s assertions that family violence had been committed.

95     Taking the Mother’s case at its highest, what transpired was that a disagreement broke out after the Mother refused to allow the Father to take [C] out to a picnic. I did not see how this could have caused the Mother or the children to be in fear of hurt. I also did not see how the Father could have the necessary intent to place the Mother in fear of hurt.

19. Incident on 1 June 2024

96     The Mother alleged that she had returned to the matrimonial flat after bringing [A] to his art class. The Father was carrying [B] in the living room while she was in the kitchen. Suddenly, the Father blurted out without any provocation, “Daddy doesn’t want to be around hateful people. Such hateful people with hateful values”. She alleged that the Father handled [B] roughly while putting him down in the playpen, causing [B] to cry. The Mother alleged that the Father did not even bother to soothe [B] and simply walked away and shouted at the Mother, “Get out of my face and out of my life”[note: 31]. The Father then went upstairs and slammed the door of the study room[note: 32].

97     In the Mother’s closing submissions, she stated that she had been in the kitchen at that time, away from the Father and had not spoken to the Father nor done anything to him before this outburst. She submitted that “it is clear that the Father is volatile and unstable. He can suddenly lose control of his temper and flare up over nothing, putting the subject of his anger in danger”. She submitted that the Father’s handling of [B] in his agitated state suggested that when the Father is angry or agitated around [B], [B] would likely to be hurt or put in fear of hurt by the Father[note: 33].

98     Having viewed the video recording and examined the transcript[note: 34], I am not convinced that the Father had put [B] down in the playpen in a rough manner as alleged by the Mother. The area in the living room where the playpen was is not large. I accepted the Father’s explanation that he put [B] down as he wanted to leave the living room so as to not to engage further with the Mother[note: 35].

99     The Mother’s own evidence showed that she was not in fear of harm. She had originally been in the kitchen, away from the Father. I failed to see how she could have been in fear since after she heard the Father blurting out that he did not want to be around hateful people, she then voluntarily chose to come out of the kitchen to the living room where the Father was with [B] before the Father then said, “Get out of my face and get out of my life”.

20. Incident on 27 July 2024

100    The Mother alleged that he had questioned the helpers in a threatening manner multiple times throughout the day after having read their affidavits. The Mother alleged that he hurled insults and expletives at her including “big liar”, “lying bitch”, “lying scum” and “vile human being”. She alleged that the Father “was standing in close proximity to (the Mother) and pointing and gesturing at (the Mother) while he insulted her. He could have hurt her physically if she had responded or retaliated to (his) tirade”[note: 36].

101    The Mother further alleged that the Father had also involved his own mother and aunt to take [C] out of the home that afternoon despite the Mother’s objections. She submitted that “by taking [C] out of the home in the context of his threatening behaviour towards (the Mother) and the helpers that day… (he) was demonstrating that he, as the aggressor and as head of the household had control and dominance over the (Mother) and the children. After parties’ affidavits were exchanged, (he) felt the need to re-exert control over the Mother and the children”[note: 37].

102    The Father denied that family violence was committed. I accepted his submissions. Although the Mother submitted multiple recordings, text messages and a police report regarding the 27 July 2024 incident, none of the evidence showed that the Father had made any threat of hurt to the Mother[note: 38]. I also note that it was the Mother who walked into the kitchen when the Father was talking to the helper. If the Mother was in fear of the Father, it defies logic that she would voluntarily walk into the kitchen and be in the Father’s way. The video also shows that the time period where the Father had interacted with the Mother in the kitchen only lasted for 40 seconds[note: 39].

My findings:

103    For all the reasons stated above, I find that the Mother has not proven her case under limb (a) in that she has not shown that the Father had willingly or knowingly placed or attempted to place the Mother or any of the children in fear of hurt.

(b) Causing hurt to a family member by such act which is known or ought to have been known would result in hurt

104    Physically abusing a family member constitutes family violence under limb (b). There are, however, two types of force which are exempted from the definition of “family violence” in s 64 of the Charter;

Force lawfully used in self-defence and

Force lawfully used by way of correction towards a child below 21 years of age (“the Correction Exception”)

105    The Mother relied on 2 incidents to support her allegation that the Father had caused hurt to her and 2 other incidents to support her allegation that the Father had caused hurt to [A]. I will consider the incidents in turn:

1. Incident in or around August 2016

106    As stated in paragraph 13 above, the Mother had alleged that the Father had pinned her hand to a cabinet and bruised her hand sometime in August 2016.

107    I had accepted the Father’s version of what transpired in paragraph 15 above, that it was the Mother who had tried to assault him, causing him to push her arm away so that she would not hit him and as a result he came into contact with the Mother’s arm. His evidence given both in his affidavit and tested during cross-examination at the trial[note: 40] was consistent that it was the Mother who had tried to assault him. There was no police report or medical evidence to the contrary. I accepted the Father’s evidence that he had acted in self-defence and I reject the Mother’s claim that the Father had committed family violence in this incident.

2. Incident on or around 22-23 May 2024

108    The only other incident where the Mother alleged that actual physical hurt was caused to her is stated in paragraph 85 above. The Mother alleged that she had called the police as she was concerned that the Father’s behaviour would escalate. The Father shouted at her and she took her phone to record him. The Father instead got in her face, taunted her for recording him, grabbed her arm and shook her violently, causing pain and soreness to her arm”.

109    I had found above in paragraph 90 that the video recording of the Father allegedly shaking the Mother was only 5 seconds long and did not show that he was shaking her violently. The Mother also did not produce any medical reports to show that she had suffered any injury or pain on her arm. Her own evidence did not suggest that she had suffered any injury, since shortly after this, she chose to go to the playpen where the Father was sitting in with [B] and ask the Father to pass [B] to her so that she could carry [B] to say goodbye before she left for work. In my judgment, the Father’s actions were in response to the Mother calling the police and taking out her phone to record him and I do not accept that actual physical hurt was caused to the Mother.

3. Incidents from 7 June 2023-12 June 2023 while parties were overseas

110    The next 2 incidents concerned [A]. The first incident occurred just after parties had taken the maxicab from the airport and arrived at their Airbnb accommodation. The only person who gave evidence that the Father had beat [A] was [E], the helper who looked after [A]. [E]’s evidence was that after they got off the maxicab, the Mother passed [A] to her parents to take care of him as the Mother was feeling very tired from carrying [A] throughout the whole flight from Singapore. [A] could not stop crying as he wanted to stick with the Mother and the Father took [A] from the Mother’s parents and “forcefully hit his buttocks and legs multiple times to stop him from crying”[note: 41].

111    [E]’s account directly contradicted the Mother’s account of what transpired. The Mother’s evidence was that it was her father who brought [A] to his own adjacent Airbnb apartment and after a while, when her father managed to soothe [A], he brought [A] back to the Mother and the Father’s Airbnb apartment but when [A] saw the Father, [A] started crying again.

112    This alleged incident of physical hurt to [A] was also completely missing from the affidavit of the Mother’s father who was allegedly the one the Father took [A] from. If the Father had indeed taken [A] from the Mother’s father and then hit [A] forcefully on his buttocks and legs multiple times according to [E]’s account, it was puzzling why this important event was not mentioned at all in the affidavit of the Mother’s father.

113    On the whole, I found it difficult to accept [E]’s account that the Father had taken [A] from the Mother’s parents and hit him as it contradicted the Mother’s own account of what had transpired and it was entirely missing from the affidavit of the Mother’s father.

114    For completeness, I will add, that even if the Father had used physical force on [A] (which I did not accept), I would have gone on to consider if this fell within the Correction Exception.

115    While there is, as the Family Court observed in VYB v VYA [2021] SGFC 121 (“VYB”) at [11], growing suggestion internationally that physical punishment produces detrimental consequences in children, the Correction Exception remains part of Singapore law.

116    If indeed the Father had spanked [A] as claimed by [E], I am of the view that it could fall within the Correction Exception if it was done for the purpose of teaching discipline with a measure of good sense, in a judicious and responsible manner, and for the benefit of the child[note: 42]. It was not in dispute that [A] was tired and had not slept well on the plane and had cried throughout the maxicab ride to the Airbnb. The Mother was very tired from carrying [A] throughout the flight and needed to rest, yet [A] still wanted to remain with the Mother. In my judgment, the Father’s correction of [A] in these circumstances would not have constituted family violence. The common law, which continues to underpin legal regulation of the relationship between parent and child in Singapore, has long supported the authority of a parent to inflict reasonable discipline on the chid, including some degree of physical punishment as long as it is a reasonable one. In VYB, the Court identified at [14] - [15], several related factors that shed light on the reasonableness of the physical punishment by a parent of a child. These include the reasons for the punishment, the nature of the punishment, and the age and personal characteristics of the child. I am of the view that the Father’s spanking of [A] on his butt and legs was not unreasonable considering the circumstances: that the Mother needed to rest after the flight but [A] was still crying and wanting to stick to her. I will also add that even if this incident of spanking could be considered harsh for a young child, consistent with the observations in TCV (On behalf of Child, A) v TCU [2015] SGFC at [14], the law does not intervene through the issuance of a PPO in every instance of parenting that exceeds the Correction Exception and a PPO will not be granted unless it is necessary for the protection of the child.

4. Incident in or around September 2023

117    This was the only other incident in the Mother’s closing submissions where it was alleged that actual physical hurt had been caused to [A].

118    As stated in paragraph 63 above, [E] had alleged that [A] woke up from his afternoon nap and cried for the Mother. The Father came into the room and yelled at [A] to stop crying but he would not stop. The Father then took a bamboo cane and beat [A] multiple times on the leg. [E]’s evidence was that this caused [A] to scream, cry even more and choke on his own saliva. He had difficulty breathing and his nose started to bleed. [E] stated that she pleaded with the Father to stop beating [A] and the Mother rushed into the room because she heard [A] scream loudly. It was only then that the Father stopped beating [A][note: 43].

119    The Father disputed this, stating that [A] had been crying non-stop for a good half an hour. He recalled that the Mother had been increasingly telling him to be stricter and to discipline [A] and the Mother herself had also just started using a cane to discipline [A]. He carried [A] in an attempt to soothe him, but [A] would not stop crying and instead started hitting him. The Father told him to stop but he would not listen and this continued for at least another half an hour. The Father then took the cane and tried to apply the Mother’s method of physical discipline. He denied that [E] had pleaded with him to stop bearing [A][note: 44].

120    I had accepted the Father’s account of the incident as stated at paragraph 65 above. As I have stated, despite the severity of the alleged beating, breathing difficulty and nosebleed, there is no evidence that medical attention was sought for [A]. The Mother herself also gave no evidence at all regarding this incident in her affidavits or on the stand, despite citing numerous other incidents less serious in nature throughout her case.

121    I will also state that I do not find that the Father’s method of discipline towards [A] was overly excessive such that it crossed the boundaries set by the Correction Exception and amounted to family violence as defined in the Charter. There is also no evidence that this correction was for the Father’s own “gratification of passion” or “rage”[note: 45] as submitted by the Mother, and I do not accept her submission.

My findings:

122    I therefore find that the Mother has not shown that the Father had caused hurt to her and/or [A] under limb (b).

(c) Wrongfully confining or restraining a family member against his or her will

123    The Mother also relied on limb (c) to state that when the Father had stood at the doorway when the Father stood at the doorway and blocked her from leaving the room with [A] in or around December 2020, he had wrongfully confined or restrained her against her will.

124    As per paragraph 31 above, the Mother had alleged that she was carrying [A] in the bedroom when her parents were out. The Father came into the room and asked to take [A]. She declined as [A] was asleep and she did not want him to be disturbed. The Father shouted at her and accused her of denying him access to [A]. He tried to snatch [A] from her and she retreated into a corner of the room to avoid him. She tried to get past the Father to leave the room but he came very close to her with his arms outstretched towards her and [A]. The Mother stated that eventually she managed to get past the Father and leave the room with [A]. She went quickly to her parents’ room where her phone was and called her father. By then, the Father had left and she returned to the bedroom with [A] and locked the door.

125    I had found earlier at paragraph 36 that it was the Mother’s actions of carrying [A], who was the subject of the disagreement, and trying to leave the room that led to the escalation of the situation. The Father’s actions merely showed that he wanted access to [A] which the Mother was refusing to give. I do not find that the Mother was confined or restrained in her room. In fact, it was her own evidence that she managed to leave the room with [A] and that she got past the Father. In my view, the Mother could easily have left [A] who was sleeping in the room and left at any point since it was access to [A] that the Father sought.

126    I therefore find that the Mother has not shown that the Father had wrongfully confined or restrained her against her will under limb (c).

(d) Continual harassment with intent to cause or knowing that it is likely to cause anguish to a family member

127    The Mother also alleged that the Father had continually harassed her and the children under limb (d). The Mother submitted that the Father’s harassing behaviour towards and the children was repeated across multiple incidents such that they constituted prolonged, persistent or sustained conduct, and even if each incident in and of itself may not be sufficient to warrant a PPO being granted, taken together, they showed a persistent course of conduct on the Father’s part to alarm and distress the Mother whenever he was upset or angry, which has caused severe and repeated anguish to the Mother[note: 46].

Saying threatening words to the Mother

128    The Mother also submitted that the Father continually harassed her with threatening words with intent to cause or knowing that it was likely to cause her anguish in the following 3 incidents[note: 47]:

1. Incident in 2020 during the Mother’s pregnancy with [A]

129    The Mother alleged that sometime during her pregnancy in 2020, the Father had demanded a divorce and told ger that it would be better if she had a miscarriage.

2. Incident on or around 25 May 2024

130    The Mother alleged that the Father threatened to forcefully bring [A] out for a picnic with his friend despite her disagreement.

3. Incident on or around 27 July 2024

131    The Mother alleged that after the Father had seen her and her witnesses’ AEICs, he threatened her to “watch out” and this caused her to feel afraid and threatened by his words.

Saying threatening words to [A]

132    The Mother submitted that the Father continually harassed [A] with threatening words with intent to cause or knowing that it was likely to cause him anguish in the following incidents[note: 48]:

1. Incidents from 7-12 June 2023 while parties were overseas

133    The Mother alleged that during their overseas trip, the Father threatened [A] as follows: on 7 June 2023 when [A] could not stop crying, the Father threatened to beat him and leave him behind. On 9 June 2023 when the Father threatened to abandon [A] in the shopping street and let passers-by take [A] away when [A] would not stop crying. On 10 June 2023, when the Father threatened [A] that the maxicab driver would take him away if he did not stop crying and on 11 June 2023, when the Father threatened to leave [A] behind when he was tired and fussy at the airport.

2. Incident in or around October or November 2023

134    The Mother submitted that in or around October or November 2023, the Father threatened to leave [A] at the top floor of the matrimonial flat when [A] cried when he was insecure being away from the Mother.

3. Incident on or around 25 May 2024

135    The Mother alleged that the Father insisted on bringing [C] to a picnic and kept shouting at the Mother who was then carrying [A] saying “Why cannot bring [C] out’. To keep [A] safe, the Mother handed [A] to his helper who brought [A] to his room.

Shouting/using vulgarities and slurs/insults in a hostile manner

1. Towards the Mother

136    The Mother submitted in the closing submissions that the Father had caused her continual harassment by shouting, using vulgarities and slurs, and/or insulting her and relied on 15 incidents from 2020 till July 2024[note: 49]. She highlighted that the Husband had apologised for the incident on or around 23 August 2020, where he had used vulgar language on her and her parents, showing that he knew such behaviour would cause distress to the Mother[note: 50].

2. Towards [A]

137    The Mother submitted that the Father had caused [A] continual harassment by shouting, using vulgarities and slurs, and/or insulting him, or shouting in his presence during 8 incidents from 2020 till July 2024[note: 51].

3. Towards the Twins

138    The Mother relied on 6 incidents of the Father’s behaviour of shouting in the presence of one or both of the twins when the Father was shouting to submit that he was likely to cause or have caused continual harassment. She further stated that “considering (his) pattern of behaviour, especially how he has treated [A] who is now 4 years old, it does not require a leap of logic to see that (the Father) would also be behaving in the same hostile and harassing manner to [B] and [C], if such behaviour goes unchecked”[note: 52].

Hitting or throwing things/pointing aggressively/cornering or following around aggressively/intruding into a safe space

139    The Mother further submitted that the Father had caused continual harassment through 3 incidents of hitting or throwing things in the incidents in or around July 2020, 23 August 2020 and 12 February 2021[note: 53].

140    She also alleged that the Father had caused her continual harassment by pointing at her aggressively during 3 incidents, namely on or around 4 May 2024, 9 May 2024 and 27 July 2024[note: 54].

141    Furthermore, she submitted that the Father cornered her or followed her around aggressively in 4 incidents, in or around December 2020, 9 May 2024, 22 and 23 May 2024 and 25 May 2024[note: 55].

142    The Mother also submitted that the Father had intruded into her safe space twice during the incidents on or around 22 and 23 May 2024[note: 56].

My findings:

143    There is no legislative definition for the term, “harassment”, as it is used in limb (d) of s 64 of the Charter. We must therefore look to the cases which have interpreted the term “harassment”.

144    The case of Yue Tock Him @ Yee Chok Him v Yee Ee Lim [2011] SGDC 99 (“Yue Tock Him”) is instructive. The District Court ruled that “harassment” means: “a course of conduct by a person, whether by words or action, directly or through third parties, sufficiently repetitive in nature as would cause, and which he ought reasonably to know would cause, worry, emotional distress or annoyance of another person”.

145    Further, the conduct that is said to constitute “harassment” must be “continual” to constitute “family violence” – a single act of harassment does not, in itself, constitute “family violence”. Following from this, “not all unpleasant or annoying behaviour between two family members will, by itself, be considered as “family violence”. Only sufficiently serious and grave conduct, which are continual and sufficiently repetitive will meet the requirement (see WDR v WDQ [2022] SGFC 46 and VKW v VKX [2020] SGFC 70).

146    These requirements may, at first glance, appear rather stringent to a victim of family violence. However, as the District Court explained in Yue Tock Him, it is necessary that the law protects against frivolous complaints that make an issue of the most trivial of matters.

147    None of the incidents either on their own, or in totality, involve serious threat of harm to the Mother or the children. They may fairly be characterised as loud and antagonistic disagreements. However, it would be inappropriate for the Court to rule that such incidents constitute family violence, without more.

148    I would also add that while the Mother cited incidents spanning from 2020 to July 2024, there are clearly several breaks in continuity between the incidents. The 21 incidents that she cited as constituting harassment occurred across more than 6 years. 1 incident occurred in 2016, 4 occurred in 2020, 3 in 2021, 1 in 2022, 4 in 2023 and 7 in 2024[note: 57]. I do not find that this demonstrated a repetitive and sustained pattern of behaviour which warranted the grant of a PPO.

149    While the Father’s conduct may not have met the highest standards of husbandhood, on the totality of the incidents alleged by the Mother, even taken at its highest, I do not find that there was sufficiently serious and grave conduct by the Father, which was continual and sufficiently repetitive as to constitute family violence.

Necessary for the protection of a family member

150    I have found above that the Mother had not shown that family violence had not been committed under any of the limbs (a) to (d). For completeness, I will go on to state that I would also not have found that the Mother had satisfied the second limb of S 65(1) of the Women’s Charter, that it was necessary on the facts to grant a PPO.

151    Necessity is determined by whether there are likely to be further acts of family violence committed against the particular family member, in the event that a PPO is not granted. This is because a PPO is not a punitive measure to punish a person for past violence but is instead a preventive order that serves to restrain the person concerned from committing family violence in future. Therefore, if it is unlikely that there will be family violence in future, it serves no purpose to restrain the party concerned, and it must follow that a personal protection order would not be necessary (Yue, at [64]).

152    Further, as the Family Court explained in WLP v WLQ [2023] SGFC 10 at [15], the concept of “necessity” implies that there must be a measure of effectiveness to the end sought. An order that is ineffective in addressing family violence will be “extraneous to and hardly necessary for the protection or personal safety of the applicant”. In other words, this statutorily prescribed requirement of necessity serves as a safeguard against unnecessary intervention by the Court in family matters.

153    The only 2 incidents cited by the Mother that allegedly involved physical harm occurred in August 2016 and then 8 years later in May 2024. I have found on the facts that no such physical harm occurred to her. All the other allegations concerned verbal disagreements that, while undoubtedly uncomfortable, do not amount to family violence. No serious incidents of physical violence or persistent harassment have been proved by the Mother. Accordingly, the granting of a PPO is not necessary in this case.

154    Specifically with regards to the children, there is currently no court order for custody, care and control and access of the children. That being the case, the Court will also be loath to intervene to issue a PPO when this may indirectly restrict or hamper the Father’s access to the children.

155    It is evident that the arrival of the children to the family unit has placed tremendous strain on the Mother. She had explained in her affidavit that all their children were conceived by way of IUI and she had undergone multiple IUI attempts in 2019 and 2022 where she received more than 1,000 hormonal injections over multiple months. The Mother stated that having gone through so much just to conceive the children, their welfare was her utmost priority. The twins were born pre-mature and she was especially concerned about their physical health. She listed the sacrifices she had made for their children, such as breastfeeding [A] until he was 2 years old despite working full-time and then subsequently breastfeeding [B] and [C] until they were 8 months old, continuing to pump milk every 3 hours for the twins’ dietary needs. She also extended her maternity leave and went on part-time and flexi-work arrangements to care for the children. She also employed 2 helpers to help with caring for each of the twins. In addition, there is a third helper who cares for [A] who has stayed with the Mother’s parents since he was born, coming over to the matrimonial flat only on weekends[note: 58]. I would urge the Father to seriously reflect on his behaviour and consider what made the Mother pursue this application against him. Although her application for a PPO has failed, this should not be construed as a victory for him. He should learn to control his temper and exercise more patience and care towards the Mother, failing which it may be that a PPO may be granted if the conflict between the parties does escalate in the future.

156    It is not uncommon that new parents of young children face considerable issues adapting to their new roles, and that disputes over different parenting styles and expectations may arise. It is evident that both parents love their children dearly. I encourage the Mother to accept as much help as she can from the Father in parenting the children and the Father to exercise much patience and care towards the Mother. Both the Mother and Father have a long journey of parenting ahead of them, a journey that can be both challenging and rewarding. The children are young and require all the love and support from both the Father and the Mother and I hope that they can do the best that they can for their children.

Domestic Exclusion Order

157    The Mother had applied for a Domestic Exclusion Order (“DEO”) against the Father in respect of the entire matrimonial home where they resided. As I have dismissed the Mother’s application for the PPOs, I will also dismiss her application for the DEO.
