17     Most of the assets in the name of the husband were not in dispute, whether as to the identity of the assets or the value of the assets. The only assets over which the spouses diverged were 475 shares in Meta Platforms, Inc, a time deposit account in OCBC Bank that the husband held jointly with his mother, and the proceeds of the sale of shares in a business called “[PB]”.

18     The spouses agreed that 475 Meta shares in the name of the husband were matrimonial assets. But they diverged over the date at which those shares were to be valued. The wife submitted that these shares were to be valued at the date of the hearing of the ancillary matters, when these shares were worth $309,415. The husband submitted that these shares were to be valued at the date of the interim judgment in May 2022, when these shares were worth only $76,090. In VQF v VQG [2024] SGHCF 4 (“VQF”) at [1], the Family Division of the High Court observed that the date for ascertaining the pool of matrimonial assets was the date of the interim judgment, which dissolved the marriage. On the other hand, the date for valuing the assets and liabilities in that pool of matrimonial assets, save for money account balances, was the date of the hearing of the ancillary matters, because that date would facilitate the use of the most up-to-date values in ascertaining the economic fruits of the marriage. The husband asserted that the four-fold increase in the value of the Meta shares should accrue solely to him because it was his decision to hold the shares beyond the date of the interim judgment that produced the increase in the value of the shares. But there was little evidence to show, as of the date of the interim judgment, that the husband was assuming solely for himself rather than for the matrimonial pool the consequences of holding the Meta shares beyond that date. Without such evidence, there was little reason to depart from the position in VQF. The date for valuing the 475 Meta shares was thus the date of the hearing of the ancillary matters. At that date, these shares had a value of $309,415.

19     It was also not in dispute that there was a time deposit with OCBC Bank in the names of the husband and his mother that had a monetary balance of $134,800. The wife submitted that this value was to be added to the pool of matrimonial assets. The husband, however, claimed that he had made no contributions to and had no beneficial interest in this time deposit or the monies therein. In support of this claim, the husband adduced an affidavit deposed by his mother in which she repeated the claim of the husband. But the husband as a joint owner of the bank account was entitled to the undivided whole of the monies in that account. On the face of his legal ownership of the account, the monies therein were matrimonial assets. Insofar as the husband asserted that he had no beneficial interest in the account, it was incumbent on him to obtain a determination from the civil courts to that effect because the Family Justice Courts were unable to adjudicate on a claim by a third party to a putative matrimonial asset (see UDA v UDB and another [2018] 1 SLR 1015 at [44]). But there was no such determination before me. Beyond the bare and self-serving assertions of the husband and his mother, there was no evidence to show that, despite the legal interest of the husband in that account, he had no beneficial interest in the monies in that account. I thus included that account in the pool of matrimonial assets and valued it at $134,800.

20     It finally appeared that the husband had received approximately $20,000 from the [PB] business. He had received this sum in two tranches, which were a fortnight apart, in September 2021, which was shortly before these divorce proceedings were commenced in December 2021. Scant explanation was offered to account for these monies. In my view, these monies were matrimonial assets.

21     Adding the values of the Meta shares ($309,415), the OCBC Time Deposit ($134,800), and the proceeds of the sale of the [PB] business shares ($20,000) to the other assets in the name of the husband, the total value of the assets in the name of the husband was $927,175.

Division of matrimonial assets

22     Based on my findings above, the pool of matrimonial assets comprised $479,124 in assets in the joint names of the spouses, $213,524 in assets in the sole name of the wife, and $927,175 in assets in the sole name of the husband. The value of the pool of matrimonial assets thus totalled $1,619,825.

23     The exercise of dividing matrimonial assets sought to fairly apportion the economic fruits of the marriage between the spouses by duly recognising their breadwinning and homemaking contributions to the marriage, in line with the philosophy that marriage was an equal partnership (see TNL at [45]). Two different approaches applied based on the nature of the breadwinning and homemaking arrangements in the marriage. In general, the “structured” approach in ANJ v ANK [2015] SGCA 34 (“ANJ”) was used, whereunder the court ascertained ratios representing: (a) the spouses’ direct contributions to the acquisition of the matrimonial assets; and (b) the spouses’ indirect contributions to the welfare of the family. These two ratios would then be averaged and necessary adjustments to the weightage of each ratio could be made to reach a fair and just division of the matrimonial assets. But the ANJ approach would not be applied in long single-income marriages because it over-recognised the financial contributions of the breadwinner and under-recognised the non-financial contributions of the homemaker. Instead, the division exercise in such circumstances tended to centre on the indirect contributions of the homemaking spouse, and the weight to be ascribed to these indirect contributions would be broadly proportional to the length of the marriage. Hence, the final ratios of division ranged from 50:50 (in long single-income marriages of 25–35 years’ duration) to 75:25 in favour of the breadwinner (in shorter single-income marriages of 10–15 years’ duration).

24     The observations of the Court of Appeal in BOR v BOS and another appeal [2018] SGCA 78 (“BOR”) at [111]–[113] were instructive:

111    … In TNL v TNK, this court observed that the trend in long single-income marriages had tended towards an equal division of matrimonial assets, but different considerations may attach to short single-income marriages (at [48]). To give some context to the terms “long” and “short”, TNL v TNK itself involved a marriage of some 35-years. The cases which the court referred to as relevant precedents involved marriages of between 26 to 30 years.

112    The marriage in the present case lasted about 11 and a half years, much shorter than the examples which the court discussed in TNL v TNK. Different considerations apply to such mid-length marriages. As we stated in ANJ v ANK at [27] (albeit in the context of discussing the structured approach), as a general rule, the longer the marriage, the more weight is given to the parties’ indirect contributions. Conversely, the shorter the marriage, the less weight will be ascribed to indirect contributions.

113    We find that the precedents are generally consistent with this principle. Thus, in ATT v ATS [2012] 2 SLR 859 at [18], we observed that the trend in “moderately lengthy marriages” was towards awarding the homemaker wife about 35% to 40% of the matrimonial assets. It would appear from the examples discussed that what was meant by “moderately lengthy” was a period in the range of around 15–18 years. For marriages of shorter duration (around 10–15 years), the trend appears to be towards awarding the non-income earning party about 25% to 35% of the matrimonial pool. Thus in UGG v UGH (m.w.) [2017] SGHCF 25, which involved a marriage of 12 and a half years, a Wife who had made minimal direct financial contributions was awarded 31.35% of the pool of matrimonial assets. In ABX v ABY and others [2014] 2 SLR 969, which involved a marriage of nine years, the homemaker wife was awarded 25% of the pool of the matrimonial assets.

25     Nevertheless, as the Family Division of the High Court cautioned in UBM v UBN [2017] 4 SLR 921, a litigant could not focus excessively on categorising a marriage as one that was single-income or dual-income. Rather, the court was ultimately guided by the philosophy that a marriage was an equal partnership, and equal and sufficient recognition had to be paid to both breadwinning and homemaking contributions. The power of dividing matrimonial assets would therefore be exercised in broad strokes.

26     This caution was apposite in these proceedings, where the wife had worked periodically for a total duration of approximately a year within the 11-year marriage. At the time of these proceedings, too, the wife was actively looking for employment and had found employment by the conclusion of these proceedings. Still, the wife submitted that the TNL approach for long single-income marriages should apply,[note: 2] and that she should be awarded 50% of the matrimonial assets.[note: 3] But given the relatively short duration of the marriage, one year of work by the wife was not insubstantial. This marriage therefore did not fit squarely within the TNL framework for long single-income marriages. The structured approach in ANJ was thus, by default, the appropriate one to take.

Direct contributions

27     The husband, who was a breadwinner throughout the marriage, paid for the matrimonial home that had a value of $479,124 and the matrimonial assets in his name that had a value of $927,175. The wife, who worked for a year during the marriage, financed the matrimonial assets in her name that had a value of $213,524. The ratio of the direct contributions of the spouses was thus 87:13 in favour of the husband.

Indirect contributions

28     For the indirect contributions of the spouses, the marriage had lasted 11 years and the wife had been the primary caregiver to the two children throughout the marriage. The husband, who was the primary breadwinner, travelled regularly for work. Yet he paid the expenses of the household, oversaw the acquisition and fitting out of the matrimonial home, and engaged domestic helpers to assist the wife with her homemaking. As the husband submitted, these indirect contributions of his helped the wife with her homemaking and freed her to obtain educational qualifications including a diploma and a master’s degree, as well as pursue full-time jobs (albeit for limited periods of time). On balance, a fair apportionment of the indirect contributions of the spouses was 60:40 in favour of the wife.

Fair and equitable division

29     Taking the average of the ratios of the direct and indirect contributions of the spouses, the final ratio was 63.5:36.5 in favour of the husband.

30     The wife urged me to award her at least a 5% uplift in this final ratio by drawing an adverse inference against the husband for a lack of full and frank disclosure of his assets. She claimed that he had provide piecemeal responses to her applications for discovery and interrogatories and had been less than candied on his transactions especially in relation to his OCBC Time Deposit and his investment in the [PB] business. But the disclosure provided by the husband in discovery and interrogatories, even if occasionally piecemeal, was generally complete. Further, it was more principled, given that the values of the OCBC Time Deposit and the proceeds from the [PB] business shares were known, to add those values to the pool of matrimonial assets rather than to provide an impressionistic uplift to the final ratio of division in favour of the wife.

31     I thus awarded the wife a 36.5% share of the $1,619,825 pool of matrimonial assets.

32     For completeness, if this marriage were classified, as submitted by the wife, as a single-income marriage, the approach in TNL would apply. Thereunder, given the 11-year length of the marriage, the wife would likely have received 25-30% of the pool of matrimonial assets. This would have been less favourable for the wife than the 36.5% share of the pool of matrimonial assets that she would receive pursuant to the structured approach in ANJ. But given that the purpose of the TNL approach (as an exception to the default ANJ approach) was to provide due recognition to the homemaking contributions in single-income marriages, it would be justified to grant the wife, who was the primary homemaker here, the more generous of the awards under the TNL approach and the ANJ approach. Accordingly, I awarded her 36.5% of the pool of matrimonial assets.

Maintenance

33     At the time of these proceedings, the husband and the wife were each approximately 50 years of age. The husband earned a monthly income of $10,737. The wife earned a monthly income of $3,500.[note: 4]

34     For wife maintenance, the wife had earned a monthly income of $6,600 before the divorce, had lost that employment thereafter, and had found work only during the hearing of the ancillary matters at a monthly income of $3,500. It was commendable that the wife had made efforts to find such gainful employment, because the law encouraged former wives to seek employment to defray their personal expenses and contribute to preserve their pre-divorce lifestyles and standards of living (see Quek Lee Tiam v Ho Kim Swee (alias Ho Kian Guan) [1995] SGHC 23 at [21]–[22] and ARY v ARX and another appeal [2016] 2 SLR 686 at [13]). Still, the difference between the monthly income of the wife before and after the divorce was substantial. It was thus just to have the husband contribute to the reasonable expenses of the wife while she found her feet after the divorce. Taking account of the not insubstantial share of the matrimonial assets that the wife would receive, I ordered the husband to maintain the wife for two years in the monthly sum of $200.

35     For child maintenance, the wife sought a monthly sum of $3,250 for each child and asked that the husband further “bear the children’s mandatory education expense including school fees, school trips and any extra lessons and/or programs organized by the school”. She added that the maintenance should be payable until the children complete their tertiary education and attain their first tertiary degree.[note: 5] The husband proposed monthly figures of child maintenance of $1,192 for the son and $1,587 for the daughter.

36     At the outset, I found it unjustified at this juncture to have the husband maintain the children beyond the age of 21 years, which was the age upon which child maintenance obligations terminate unless otherwise ordered by the court (see s 69(6) of the Women’s Charter 1961 (2020 Rev Ed)). The children were 13 and 11 years of age respectively. There was no certainty that they would be pursuing education beyond 21 years of age. As the Family Court in XFP v XFQ [2024] SGFC 97 observed at [10]–[12], maintenance catered to present and certain financial needs and not potential or uncertain aspirational wants. Absent certainty that the children would be pursing tertiary education, it would be unjustified to order maintenance to that effect.

37     As for the quantum of maintenance, the wife offered no breakdown for how each child spent $3,250 per month. Instead, she tabulated a detailed list of what she called “nocturnal activities” on the part of the husband then demanded that he put up $6,500 each month for the children.[note: 6] She appeared to premise her claim for $3,250 per child per month on the basis that the husband should be fully responsible for maintaining the children because he had a higher earning capacity than her.

38     The husband, on his part, likewise offered few specifics on the expenses of each child beyond asserting that $1,192 for the son and $1,587 for the daughter comprised 62% of the reasonable expenses of each of them.

39     Based on the submissions of the spouses, the following expenses of the children were not in dispute:

(a)     Student care: $245 per month per child

(b)     School transport: $123 per month per child

(c)     Pocket money: $160 per month per child

40     Over and above these sums, the wife justified her claims for child maintenance on the basis that the children attended tuition and incurred expenditures on “daily living necessities such as food and grocery expenses, transportation costs, personal care, clothing and other miscellaneous needs”.[note: 7] For tuition, in particular, the wife submitted that the son incurred $1,434 each month while the daughter incurred $450 each month.

41     As between the submissions of the husband and the wife on child maintenance, I found the submissions of the husband more credible. Even as neither spouse provided detailed breakdowns of the expenses of each child, the submissions of the wife were more difficult to accept for three reasons. First, she claimed that the reasonable expenses of each child were the same when, on her own calculations, the son spent approximately $1,000 more than the daughter on tuition each month and the other expenses of each child were broadly similar. Second, on the calculations of the wife, the daughter would be spending over $2,000 each month just on food and groceries, clothing, and other miscellaneous needs, which estimate was objectively high. Third, the wife appeared to premise her claim for child maintenance on the basis that the husband should maintain the children solely when the maintenance of children is a joint parental responsibility and she was not without earning capacity. Indeed, at the time of these proceedings, the wife was seeking work at the Singapore Corporate Counsel Association.

42     I thus preferred the estimates of the husband as to the reasonable expenses of the children and his proposals to pay $1,192 for the son and $1,587 for the daughter each month. The maintenance of the children was a joint parental responsibility, and the wife was not without financial resources to play her part in discharging that responsibility given the not insignificant amount of matrimonial assets that she would receive as well as the employment income that she had recently secured. Still, the wife would, even when she secured employment, require some time to settle into a breadwinning role after serving as a homemaker for much of the marriage. I thus ordered the husband to maintain the children in amounts that were slightly higher than those that he had put forward. The husband was thus to maintain the children until they attained 21 years of age in the monthly sums of $1,300 for the son and $1,800 for the daughter.

Conclusion

43     I thus made the following orders:

(a)     The pool of matrimonial assets, which had a value of, was to be divided in the proportions of 62.5% to the husband and 36.5% to the wife.

(b)     The husband was to maintain the wife in the monthly sum of $200 for two years.

(c)     The husband was to maintain the children until they attained 21 years of age in the monthly sums of $1,300 for the son and $1,800 for the daughter.

44     I made no order on the costs of these proceedings.

XIM v XIN

XIM v XIN
[2025] SGFC 17

Case Number:Divorce No 228 of 2023
Decision Date:10 February 2025
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Marcus Ho
Counsel Name(s): Chan Eng Jin, Darren (Zeng Yongren, Darren) and David Zhang (Legal Aid Bureau) for the plaintiff; Lim Hong Wen, Amelia and Low Seow Ling (Liu Xiaolin) (Emre Legal LLC) for the defendant.
Parties: XIM — XIN

Family Law – Matrimonial assets – Division – Dissipation of shares

10 February 2025

District Judge Marcus Ho:

Introduction

1       The Plaintiff Wife and the Defendant Husband were married on 2 October 2011. The Plaintiff filed her Writ for Divorce on 16 January 2023. The interim judgment was granted on 12 April 2023 (the “IJ”).

2       The Plaintiff was 53 years old at the time of hearing. The Defendant was 63 years old. There were no children of the marriage, although the Plaintiff had two adult children from his previous marriage and the Defendant had one adult child from her previous marriage.

3       The ancillary matters came up before me for hearing on 19 September 2024. I delivered my decision on 25 October 2024. The only issues for my determination were the division of the matrimonial assets and spousal maintenance. In respect of the former, the parties had agreed on the pool of matrimonial assets, save that the Plaintiff contended that: (i) the Defendant had wrongfully dissipated his shares in Company X, and that a certain sum should consequently be added back into the pool of matrimonial assets to account for this; and (ii) that the Defendant had transferred a sum of $71,356.44 to his friend which should be added back into the pool.

4       I ultimately determined that: (i) a sum of $101,874.69 should be added back into the pool of matrimonial assets on account of the shares that were dissipated by the Defendant; and (ii) the sum of $71,356.44 transferred by the Defendant to his friend should also be added back into the pool. I valued the total pool of matrimonial assets at $1,096,817.10 and determined that this should be divided in the proportion of 75% to the Defendant and 25% to the Plaintiff. I further ordered that there should be no spousal maintenance for the Plaintiff.

5       The Plaintiff has since appealed specifically against my computation of the amount to be added back into the pool of matrimonial assets owing to the Defendant’s dissipation of his shares in Company X. My decision here will therefore focus on this issue.

The parties’ cases

6       Company X was incorporated in 2009 by the Defendant and his friend, A. They each contributed $10,000 towards the start-up capital. The Defendant and A were the only directors and shareholders of the company.

7       On 19 May 2015, the Defendant transferred all 250,000 of his shares in Company X to his elder child, C1. C1 was 23 years old and a university student at the time. This transfer was approved by himself and A as directors of Company X[note: 1]. On the same day, the Defendant tendered his letter of resignation to relinquish his position as a director of Company X.

8       For reasons that are disputed, though his shares were transferred to C1 on 19 May 2015, the Defendant continued as a director of Company X until 21 August 2018, when C1 was made a director of the company in his place. C1 was 26 years old at that point, and remained a university student.

9       Although the Defendant had ceased to be the legal owner of the shares as at the date of the interim judgment, the Plaintiff nevertheless posited that the value of those shares should be added to the pool of matrimonial assets. The Plaintiff’s case was that the transfer of the Defendant’s shares in Company X to C1 was an act of wrongful dissipation intended to deplete the pool of matrimonial assets at a time where the divorce was imminent. The Plaintiff argued that the shares were sold to C1 at an undervalue, that the Defendant’s narrative surrounding the disposal of his shares was untrue, and that the Defendant’s explanation for the transfer was unbelievable.

10     The Defendant’s position was that the sale of his shares to C1 was a legitimate one done at a fair and accurate market value. The Defendant disagreed that divorce proceedings were imminent at the time of sale. The Defendant consequently objected to the value of the shares being added to the pool of matrimonial assets.

Issues to be determined and the applicable law

11     Generally, the starting point in an exercise to divide the matrimonial assets is the identification of matrimonial assets and their respective values. The default operative date to determine the assets in the matrimonial pool is the date of the interim judgment, though the court retains the discretion to depart from this default position (see ARY v ARX and another appeal [2016] 2 SLR 686 at [31]).

12     However, simply identifying all the assets and liabilities in existence as at the operative date may not always sufficiently reflect the true material gains of the marriage, and therefore may not result in a just and equitable division of the matrimonial assets. This may be the case where an asset was expended prior to the operative date, such that the value of the asset would not be reflected in the pool of assets, to the benefit of the party who disposed of the asset.

13     To achieve an equitable outcome, the court is therefore empowered to add certain sums back into the pool of matrimonial assets. Where divorce proceedings are imminent, the court may order a substantial sum expended by one party to be returned to the pool of matrimonial assets if the other spouse was considered to have at least a putative interest in it and had not agreed to the expenditure, whether or not the expenditure was a deliberate attempt to dissipate matrimonial assets or not (see TNL v TNK and another appeal and another matter [2017] 1 SLR 609 (“TNL”) at [24]).

14     Further, even before divorce is imminent (or the grant of interim judgment), where it is proven on the facts and evidence that an expenditure amounts to wrongful dissipation with the intention of depleting the matrimonial pool, the court may add a sum back into the pool of matrimonial assets (see UZN v UZM [2021] 1 SLR 426 at [66] to [68]).

15     With the relevant authorities in mind, I considered the following two questions to determine whether the value of the shares in the company should be added to the pool:

(a)     Were divorce proceedings imminent at or around May 2015; and

(b)     Did the transfer of the Defendant’s shares in Company X amount to wrongful dissipation?

16     If I were to determine that the value of the shares should be added to the pool of matrimonial assets, then I would have to decide what notional amount I should add to the pool to account for the Defendant’s dissipation of his shares in Company X.

My decision

Issue 1: Whether divorce proceedings were imminent at or around May 2015

17     I first considered if divorce proceedings were imminent at or around the time that the Defendant transferred the shares to C1, i.e. on 19 May 2015. If divorce was imminent, I could, per the dicta in TNL, add the value of the shares back to the pool of matrimonial assets, whether or not the Defendant had deliberately attempted to dissipate the shares.

18     The Plaintiff argued that the parties’ marital relationship was no longer functioning at this time, and that divorce between the parties was imminent. The circumstances drawn up by the Plaintiff were as such: in April 2015, the Defendant committed family violence against her. This led to the Plaintiff applying for a personal protection order in or around May 2015, which she subsequently withdrew upon the Defendant providing an undertaking at a mention on 23 June 2015 that he would not use family violence against her. Around this time, the Defendant threatened her with divorce and reduced her allowance. Viewed as a whole, the Plaintiff submitted that the Defendant’s conduct indicated that the ‘prospect of divorce’ was already on his mind at the time. The Plaintiff suggested that the Defendant only withheld filing for a divorce at that time to avoid exposing his plan to dissipate his shares in Company X.

19     However, the Statement of Particulars (Amendment No. 1), which formed the basis for the grant of the IJ, did not rely exclusively on events in or around May 2015; nor did it cite the events in or around May 2015 as the core reason for the divorce. Rather, it referred to events even after May 2015 and suggested that the parties’ relationship had deteriorated over the years after the altercation in 2015, and that it was a cumulation of events that resulted in the breakdown of the marriage.

20     The fact of the matter is that the Writ for Divorce was only filed some eight years later. The Plaintiff withdrew the PPO, ostensibly with the hope of reconciliation. After May 2015, the parties even went on various overseas holidays as a couple between 2017 and 2019.[note: 2] The Plaintiff could have filed for a divorce herself at any time earlier, but did not do so. She consciously chose to stay in the marriage, even if for material reasons only. In the Plaintiff’s affidavits, she expressed her disappointment at the Defendant’s efforts to the marriage, which suggested that she continued to hold expectations of him as her husband over the years, even after 2015.

21     It therefore appeared to me that the love might have been lost, but the marriage very much remained. I was not satisfied on the evidence that divorce was imminent at that point in time, and did not accept the Plaintiff’s hypothesis that the Defendant only resisted filing for a divorce all those years just to avoid exposing his plan to dissipate his shares in Company X.

Issue 2: Whether the transfer of the Defendant’s shares in Company X amounted to wrongful dissipation

22     Notwithstanding my finding that the divorce was not imminent in May 2015, I examined if the Defendant’s shares in Company X were wrongfully dissipated. If so, the court may nevertheless add the value of these shares back into the pool of matrimonial assets, even if divorce was not imminent at the time.

Were the Defendant’s shares transacted at an undervalue?

23     I first considered the value of the consideration that the Defendant said he received for the shares. While the adequacy of the consideration received might not in itself be determinative of the legitimacy of the transfer, the disposal of shares for consideration less than its true value might indicate that the transfer should not simply be taken at face value.

24     In this regard, the Defendant’s position was that the consideration of $150,000 was intentionally calculated to “accurately reflect the market value of the shares”.[note: 3] The Defendant explained his calculation as follows:

(a)     The principal amount of $359,820.98, based on the Net Asset Value (“NAV”) of the 250,000 shares in Company X as reflected in the IRAS Working Sheet C for Transfer of Shares (“IRAS Working Sheet”);[note: 4]

(b)     Divided by two, i.e. $179,910.49, because half of the shares were held on C1’s behalf, and that C1 therefore only needed to pay him for the Defendant’s half of the shares; and

(c)     Less the sum of $29,500, being the Defendant’s estimation of the company’s losses in 2015.

25     Shy of any better evidence, I accepted the NAV as reflected in the IRAS Working Sheet. This document purported to contain information from the company’s management accounts as at 31 January 2015, which preceded the events in April 2015 cited by the Plaintiff. There was nothing put forth by the Plaintiff to suggest that the information in the IRAS Working Sheet was inaccurate or unreliable, nor did the valuers engaged by the Plaintiff (the “Plaintiff’s Valuers”) suggest that there was something untoward about it.

26     However, I found the rest of the Defendant’s formula to be problematic.

27     Firstly, there was a slight inaccuracy in the Defendant’s calculation, as applying his formula should result in the amount of $150,410.49, not $150,000. No explanation was given for using the lesser sum, not even an explanation that he chose to round it down for convenience.

28     Secondly, by the Defendant’s own admission, there were no documents or correspondences exchanged between Company X, C1 and himself evidencing how the consideration of $150,000 was actually determined at the time of the transfer.[note: 5]

29     Thirdly, and importantly, I did not accept the Defendant’s reasons for dividing the NAV of his 250,000 shares in two. The Defendant claimed that C1, who was only around 17 years old at the time, was the beneficial owner of half the shares because he used $5,000 of C1’s ang bao monies (that the Defendant had saved up over the years on C1’s behalf) toward the start-up capital of Company X. I found this be a weak and baseless claim:

(a)     There was no documentary evidence showing that the Defendant had taken a sum of $5,000 that belonged to C1, or that C1 was the beneficial owner of half of the shares, whether such evidence took the form of a trust deed, or even contemporaneous emails or messages. The Defendant simply relied on a bare assertion that at the material time, he had a verbal agreement with C1 that he would hold C1’s shares in his name.[note: 6] I noted that this assertion was not even something that C1 himself corroborated on affidavit, despite C1 having filed two affidavits in these proceedings;

(b)     It seemed inconceivable that the Defendant did not have the sum of $5,000 at his disposal at the time, such that he had to rely on C1’s savings. There was also no explanation as to why the Defendant could not have taken this sum of $5,000 as a loan from C1 instead. Similarly, there was no explanation as to why he did not include C1 as a shareholder of the company any earlier, if he was indeed the beneficial owner of half of the Defendant’s shares;

(c)     Further, on the face of the documents titled “Return of Allotment of Shares” dated 1 November 2011[note: 7] and 14 August 2013[note: 8], 75,000 shares were allotted to the Defendant on 26 October 2011 and 10,000 shares were allotted to the Defendant on 7 August 2013. The documents indicated that there were further cash payments made to acquire those shares. However, there was no evidence that C1 had put up any further cash payments toward those shares, such that any shares from further allotments should be attributed to him too. While the Defendant suggested that C1 had a 25% interest in the company’s profit and returns, and that a portion of such profits was reinvested over the years, I noted that there was no evidence of C1 receiving any corresponding share of dividends or profits over the years. There was also no evidence proving this arrangement or showing C1’s agreement to this arrangement. The affidavits filed by C1 also did not attest to such an arrangement.

30     Lastly, there was no objective evidence showing what the company’s losses were in 2015 to support how the Defendant arrived at the figure of $29,500. That was simply an estimate that he had decided on his own, with no apparent basis whatsoever.[note: 9] There was also no explanation as to why the sum of $29,500 was only deducted from half of the NAV of the 250,000 shares and was not first deducted from the full NAV before dividing the remainder by two, which would have resulted in a different balance of $165,160.49 instead. This appeared to me to be a contrived attempt at backward reasoning to justify the figure of $150,000.

31     I therefore found that the consideration of $150,000 was not commensurate with the value of the shares. This was also the finding arrived at by the Plaintiff’s Valuers.[note: 10] The fact that the Defendant accepted this amount, which was much lower than its NAV, and which was derived at without any coherent method of calculation, suggested that the transaction might not have been done at arm’s length. I noted that the Defendant never explained that he had accepted a consideration of lower value on account of his relationship with C1, though this might have been understandable, and perhaps even reasonable. Rather, the Defendant was constant in his insistence that the transfer had been done at fair market value. I therefore held the Defendant to this standard in examining the veracity of his claim, and found that he fell short.

Was the Defendant’s explanation for transferring the shares in May 2015 credible?

32     To explain his decision to transfer his shares to C1, the Defendant reasoned that around the time of the transfer, the parties’ relationship was strained and that for a prolonged period of time, he “lost sleep due to the Plaintiff’s behaviour at home”. The Defendant felt that with his increasing workload and his struggle with the English language, he was unable to perform his role as a director properly. The Defendant felt stressed and under pressure and therefore decided to resign and transfer his shares on 19 May 2015.[note: 11]

33     These did not strike me as very compelling reasons for disposing of his shares at the time that he did. Company X had been operating since 2009 and had been profitable over the years.[note: 12] It did not seem to me that the Defendant’s deficiencies with the English language, if any, had been a hindrance to him conducting his business effectively, and it seemed odd that he would see this as a challenge after six years of operating the company.

34     Furthermore, these operational burdens would have arisen from his role as a director, not a shareholder. The Defendant could have simply resigned from his role as director, without having to give up his shares. Rather, the opposite happened, as he sold his shares but had to remain as director for another three years or so. This would have done little to relieve him of the burdens he supposedly felt about the job. It also did not make sense to me that he found his ownership of his shares so stressful, yet so readily passed this apparent ‘poison chalice’ on to his son, without harbouring any similar concerns.

35     Apart from an allusion to the business being a private company, there was no actual explanation as to why the Defendant decided to sell his shares to C1, and not anyone else. There was no evidence that this sale was something he had been considering for some time, nor was there any evidence of any attempt to sell these shares at a higher value to A or to another third party. I noted that the Defendant did not inform the Plaintiff of the transfer of the shares in Company X, and that the Plaintiff only found out on her own much later. If this was a legitimate arrangement with nothing untoward about it, there was no reason for him to have kept the Plaintiff in the dark this whole time.

36     In light of the above, I did not find the Defendant’s reasons to be credible, particularly in the context of the state of the parties’ relationship at the time. The Defendant’s explanation did not resolve my suspicions, but conversely raised further doubts about the transaction, and gave a sense that the Defendant was obfuscating the truth. I therefore found that that the transfer of shares was, on the balance of probabilities, done with the intention of keeping them beyond the Plaintiff’s reach and depleting the pool of matrimonial assets, particularly given the lack of trust between the parties at the time.

Issue 3: The amount that should be added to the pool of matrimonial assets to account for the Defendant’s wrongful dissipation

37     Having decided that the Defendant had wrongfully dissipated his shares in Company X, it remained for me to determine the notional value to be added back into the pool of matrimonial assets. In this regard, I considered the operative date for determining the value of the shares that were dissipated, and whether the full value of these shares as at said operative date should be added back into the pool of matrimonial assets for division.

What is the operative date for determining the value of the dissipated shares?

38     The Plaintiff’s position was that the value of 250,000 shares in Company X should added to the pool of matrimonial assets at their present value. To this end, the Plaintiff argued that the 250,000 shares should be valued at $1,930,000, being what the Plaintiff’s Valuers found to be their value as at 31 January 2023.[note: 13] I noted that 31 January 2023 was a date prior to the interim judgment but was nevertheless the latest available valuation.

39     Without going into the correctness of the Plaintiff’s Valuers’ Valuation Report, I did not agree with the Plaintiff’s position.

40     The Plaintiff’s position was premised on the trite proposition that matrimonial assets are generally valued at the date of the ancillary matters hearing, or as close to the date as possible. However, the court retains the discretion from this where warranted on the facts and where there are cogent reasons to do so (see BPC v BPB and another appeal [2019] 1 SLR 608 at [42] and [43]).

41     In this case, it was not the shares that were being added back into the pool of matrimonial assets, but the notional value of those shares to account for the Defendant’s dissipation. An addition of any amount to the pool of matrimonial assets would have been by virtue of an exercise of discretion to correct the wrongful dissipation, and not by virtue of the Defendant’s ownership of the shares. Accordingly, I was of the view that it was the value of the shares as at the time of dissipation that should be added to the pool of matrimonial assets, not the latest value of the shares as though they had remained an asset in the pool of matrimonial assets.

42     As at the time of the hearing, C1 was the legal and beneficial owner of the shares. There was no evidence that C1 held these shares on trust for the Defendant. It would have been artificial and unduly prejudicial to the Defendant to adopt the latest value of the shares. It is anyone’s guess how Company X would have grown over the years had the Defendant remained a 50% shareholder of the company rather than C1, bearing in mind that shareholders are entitled to vote at meetings and thereby influence the company’s business decisions too. It is not the court’s place to dabble in such speculation, and it would be unfair on the Defendant to hold him to such speculative value where he has had no entitlement to any such gain in value from 2015 to 2023. If the reverse occurred and the value of the shares decreased significantly, or if the company had ceased its operation completely, it may be unfair on the Plaintiff if nothing was added back to the pool to account for the Defendant’s dissipation, where the shares were of considerable value at the time of dissipation.

43     In any case, I found that it would be onerous on the Defendant to add the full value proposed by the Plaintiff, which would have been close to double what I had found to be the total value of the pool of matrimonial assets. As there was no evidence that the Defendant had any interest in the shares since 19 May 2015, and similarly no evidence that he received any dividends from the company that had flowed from such interest since then, the Defendant would not have been able to tap on any commensurate gains in the shares over the years. This would have been prejudicial to his ability to satisfy any division order made. I did not think that this would have led to an equitable outcome in this case.

44     It remains to be said that one of the key reasons that led to my finding of dissipation was that the transfer of shares to C1 was done at an undervalue. If the consideration paid was not $150,000, but closer to its NAV instead, I might not have found the transaction to amount to a dissipation but rather a mere liquidation of assets, and consequently might not have decided to add the value of the shares back into the pool of matrimonial assets.

45     I therefore found on the justice of the case that adopting the value of the shares as at the time of dissipation, i.e. in May 2015, would be sufficient to account for the Defendant’s dissipation, whereas it would have been excessive to adopt the latest value of the shares.

Should the full value of the Defendant’s 250,000 shares be added to the pool?

46     As a starting point to compute the value of the shares to be added to the pool of matrimonial assets, I found it appropriate to adopt the NAV as declared in the IRAS Working Sheet, i.e. $359,820.98.

47     As mentioned above, there was no evidence that the information in the IRAS Working Sheet was inaccurate or unreliable. On the face of the IRAS Working Sheet, the NAV of the shares transferred was calculated by deducting the value of the company’s total assets less the value of its total liabilities as declared as at 31 January 2015, divided by two (as the Defendant held 250,000 out of 500,000 shares). Given the dearth of information available as to the company’s finances at the time, the Plaintiff’s Valuers found the NAV method to be the only viable option to determine an estimate of the company’s minimum value.[note: 14]

48     I noted that the Plaintiff had previously issued a summons for discovery of, among other things, financial documents for the financial years ending 31 January 2015 and 31 January 2016, but subsequently withdrew her application. Nevertheless, the financial statements for Company X for the financial years ending 31 January 2017 and 31 January 2018 were in evidence.[note: 15] These statements contained information relating to the company’s net assets for 2016, 2017 and 2018. Based on these statements, the total net assets for these years were respectively valued at $646,539, $531,480, and $523,568. Each of these values were lower than the NAV accepted for the financial year ending 31 January 2015. This suggested to me that the NAV of $719,641.96 (for all 500,000 shares) might not have been too far off, and was certainly not unrealistically low as a representation of the value of the shares as at May 2015.

49     The question that remained was whether I should simply add the full NAV of the dissipated shares, i.e. $359,820.98, back into the pool of matrimonial assets.

50     In this regard, I found that of the total of 250,000 shares, 75,000 were acquired before the marriage. This was evident from the Return of Allotment of Shares lodged on 1 November 2011, which showed that 75,000 shares were allotted to the Defendant on 26 October 2011, bringing his total shareholding at the time to 150,000 shares. There was no suggestion that any further shares were acquired between the date of the parties’ marriage (2 October 2011) and 26 October 2011. The likely inference was therefore that the Defendant had acquired 75,000 shares prior to the marriage.

51     In my assessment, these shares had not been converted into a matrimonial asset by way of either party having “ordinarily used or enjoyed” the shares, per Section 112(10)(a)(i) of the Women’s Charter 1961 (the “Charter”), as I did not find that the Defendant working for the company and using any income received from this company toward family expenses to constitute ‘usage’ or ‘enjoyment’. There was also no suggestion that these shares were “substantially improved” on by the Defendant, per Section 112(10)(a)(ii) of the Charter.

52     I also did not accept the ‘commingling’ argument run by the Defendant. Unlike monies in a bank account, I found that the shares were distinct and separately identifiable, and that there would be no issues tracing and separating the pre-marital shares from those acquired after the marriage. That there might have been some commingling of the dividends received by the Defendant only went so far as to suggest that the dividends might constitute matrimonial assets, but this was not the issue before me. I therefore found that the corresponding value of these 75,000 shares retained their character as pre-marital assets and should be excluded from the pool of matrimonial assets.

53     The NAV of the remaining 175,000 was therefore $251,874.686. Of this amount, I found that the sum of $150,000, being the amount paid by C1 to the Defendant as consideration for the transfer of the shares in Company X, should be deducted from the notional value to be added back to the matrimonial pool.

54     This sum of $150,000 was evidenced by an image of a cheque issued by Company Y,[note: 16] which was a sole proprietorship registered by C1 in 15 May 2014.[note: 17] The Plaintiff argued that it was incredible that C1 had the sum of $150,000 in his possession at the time. However, in my view, that it was equally unlikely that C1 would register a business if he had no such enterprise going on at the time, and that it was similarly unlikely for the Defendant and the C1 to have hatched a scheme register this business as a ruse just to execute this dissipation, given that Company Y was incorporated nearly a year prior to the transfer of shares on 19 May 2015. The Plaintiff did not further pursue her application for discovery against C1 and did not provide any concrete evidence to indicate that the monies were not C1’s, or that there were no monies paid out by C1 to the Defendant.

55     While there were no documents showing the Defendant’s receipt of this sum, the Defendant had explained that he was unable to retrieve the relevant bank account statements, given the passage of time.[note: 18] The Plaintiff did not pursue this matter in any application for discovery, and did not specifically question or dispute the receipt of this sum in her affidavit or in her submissions. In these premises, I found on the balance of probabilities that the Defendant had indeed received this sum of $150,000.

56     Consequently, I found that the sum of $150,000 should be deducted from the NAV of 175,000 shares ($251,874.686). I therefore decided to notionally add back into the pool of matrimonial assets the balance sum of $101,874.69.

Conclusion

57     For the reasons set out above, I ultimately found that adding the sum of $101,874.69 back into the pool of matrimonial assets was the most appropriate and equitable redress for the Defendant’s wrongful dissipation of his shares in Company X in May 2015.

XHU v XHV

XHU v XHV
[2025] SGFC 11

Case Number:Divorce No 182 of 2024 (Summons No 3441 of 2024)
Decision Date:27 January 2025
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Soh Kian Peng
Counsel Name(s): Sabrina Wong Xue Yun, Wong Soo Chih (SC Wong Chambers LLC) for the plaintiff; the defendant in person and unrepresented.
Parties: XHU — XHV

Family Law – Procedure – Discovery

27 January 2025

Judgment reserved

Assistant Registrar Soh Kian Peng:

1       Parties were married on 12 June 1985. They had four children together. It was a marriage that, up to the time the Wife filed for divorce on 12 January 2024, had lasted for almost 39 years.

2       Interim judgment was granted on 20 June 2024. Thereafter, parties set a course for the hearing of the ancillary matters. It is in this context that the Husband had taken out this application for discovery vide SUM 3441/2024 (“SUM 3441”).

3       I heard the matter on 20 January 2025. This is my decision.

4       These were the two items which the Husband had asked for in respect of discovery:

(a)     All Whatsapp messages between the Wife and [A], including those in the deleted folder, for the period January 2020 to October 2024 (“Item 1”).

(b)     All Whatsapp messages between the Wife and [B], including those in the deleted folder, for the period January 2020 to October 2024 (“Item 2”).

5       During the hearing, the Husband offered two reasons as to why the Wife should be ordered to disclose these Whatsapp messages. First, to prove that she had committed adultery with these two men, [A] and [B], and second, to prove that because of the “wayward” lifestyle she had lived, she could not have made significant financial contributions to the marriage.

6       Counsel for the Wife, on the other hand, made two broad points as to why disclosure of these Whatsapp messages should not be ordered. First, that there was no prima facie evidence that these messages had, at any time, been in the Wife’s possession custody or power.[note: 1] Second, and in any event, the Husband had not shown that the Whatsapp messages were relevant and necessary to the hearing of the ancillary matters – the discovery process should not be used to “excavate imaginary bones in the closet” and even if there was any evidence of adultery, it was clearly not relevant to the disputed issues insofar as the ancillary matters were concerned.[note: 2]

7       It is well established that when it comes to applications for discovery, the court is guided by the twin principles of relevance and necessity – in other words, the party seeking discovery must show that these documents are both relevant and necessary to the issues in dispute: WWS v WWT [2024] SGFC 24 at [22] and [24] citing UJN v UJO [2018] SGFC 47.

8       In addition, the court in VTQ v VTR [2021] SGFC 85 had (at [64]) also noted that a pre-requisite to the court’s power to order discovery is that there must be some prima facie evidence that the documents sought do indeed exist:

64    A prerequisite to the court’s power to order discovery is that there must be some evidence that the document requested is or has at any time been in the respondent’s possession, custody or power. The standard of proof is that of a prima facie case: see Alliance Management SA v Pendleton Lane P and another and another suit [2007] SGHC 133 (at [24]). In the present case, I find that there is prima facie evidence of the existence of the bank account by way of inference drawn from the evidence given by the Wife as explained above.

9       In the present case, the Husband had merely asserted, during the hearing, that his younger daughter had allegedly chanced upon these messages. This was not something that I could take notice of given that it was not stated on affidavit.

10     I also note that while the Husband had, in his 1st Affidavit of Asset and Means, gone into some detail about the Wife’s two alleged affairs, he had not exhibited any documentary evidence to corroborate his allegations. There was nothing that had been exhibited in the affidavits before me to indicate, on a prima facie basis, the existence of such messages.

11     Even assuming that there was such prima facie evidence, the Whatsapp messages were neither relevant, nor necessary to the hearing of the ancillary matters. I do not accept the Husband’s argument that the Whatsapp messages were relevant in that they would show that the Wife could not have made financial contributions to the family because of her “wayward lifestyle” as evinced by her alleged acts of adultery. Even if these messages existed, they would only cast light on the nature of the relationship between the Wife, and [A] and [B] – it would hardly go towards showing the extent of the direct, or indirect, financial contributions which the Wife had made.

12     The Husband’s application in SUM 3441 is thus dismissed. For the avoidance of doubt, nothing that I have said here shall bind the hands of the judge hearing the ancillary matters. The time limited for filing an appeal shall begin to run from the date of this judgment.

13     Unless parties are able to agree on the issue of costs, they are to tender their written submissions on costs by way of letter to court. This shall be done no later than 10 February 2025, and these submissions shall not exceed 3 pages.

[note: 1]Wife’s Written Submissions at para 5 citing VTQ v VTR [2021] SGFC 85 at [64].

[note: 2]Wife’s Written Submissions at para 12.

html:
XHW v XHX

XHW v XHX
[2025] SGFC 12

Case Number:Divorce No 4355 of 2023 (Summons No 3472 of 2024)
Decision Date:27 January 2025
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Soh Kian Peng
Counsel Name(s): Chan Xian Yi, Jonathan (Zeng Xianyi) (Chia Wong Chambers LLC) for the plaintiff; Lim Fang-Yu Mathea (PKWA Law Practice LLC) for the defendant.
Parties: XHW — XHX

Family Law – Procedure – Discovery

Family Law – Procedure – Interrogatories

27 January 2025

Judgment reserved

Assistant Registrar Soh Kian Peng:

1       Parties were married in the United Kingdom sometime in July 2009. They lived in various countries until 2019, when they decided to settle down in Singapore. It was also in 2019 that parties welcomed the one and only child to their marriage.

2       In this case, it was the Wife who had filed for divorce on 8 September 2023, citing the Husband’s unreasonable behaviour as the reason behind the irretrievable breakdown of their marriage.

3       The Statement of Particulars (Amendment No 1) sets out details of how their marriage had broken down, as well as details of their habitual residence in Singapore, which forms the basis for this court’s jurisdiction over their divorce.

4       Interim judgment was obtained on 25 January 2024. Thereafter, parties plotted a course for the hearing of the ancillary matters. It is in this context that the Wife has taken out an application for discovery and interrogatories vide SUM 3472/2024 (“SUM 3472”).

5       I heard the application on the bulk list and reserved judgment. This is my decision.

Wife’s Application for Interrogatories

6       It is well established that the court will only order interrogatories if those interrogatories are both relevant and necessary to the hearing of the ancillary matters: WWS v WWT [2024] SGFC at [22]. It is also well established that the court, at the interlocutory stage, is not concerned with the truth of any answers given to an interrogatory, but rather, whether that answer is sufficient: WXG v WXH [2024] SGFC 32 at [9] – [11]; WWS v WWT [2024] SGFC 24 at [28] – [30].

7       At the hearing before me, counsel for the Wife, Mr Jonathan Chan (“Mr Chan”) confirmed that, where the interrogatories were concerned, the Wife was only proceeding in respect of four out of the five items which she had originally sought in SUM 3472. I shall deal with them in turn.

8       I first deal with the Wife’s request in Items 1 and 3:

(a)     Item 1 was a request for the Husband to state and explain the whereabouts and purpose of several recurring withdrawals/payments from his HSBC account ending -21. These transactions ranged in value from £500 – £990.

(b)     Item 3 was a request for the Husband to state and explain the current whereabouts and purpose(s) of the several recurring monthly withdrawals from his HSBC premier account ending -1.

9       Counsel for the Husband, Ms Mathea Lim (“Ms Lim”), argued that the Husband should not have to answer these interrogatories on the basis that the transactions involved are insubstantial. In support of this argument, they cite my earlier decisions in XDD v XEE [2024] SGFC 79 and WXE v WXF [2024] SGFC 29 for the proposition that the process of discovery and interrogatories should not be used as an exercise in forensic accounting. Ms Lim had also highlighted in written submissions that the Husband had explained that these transactions made in the UK were for the payment of bills, and that they have been made on a regular basis since the family had relocated to Singapore.[note: 1]

10     I do not find that the Wife’s request in Items 1 and 3 was an attempt to engage in a forensic accounting exercise. I agree with the point Mr Chan had made – that these expenses, which were not insignificant, were rather odd given that the parties had relocated from the UK to Singapore. In this vein, it is clear to me that this interrogatory is indeed relevant and necessary to the hearing of the ancillary matters – it would show why the Husband had continued to incur and pay for expenses in the UK although parties were no longer living there, and how he had managed to do so especially given that he had stated that he had been unemployed for the past 3 years.[note: 2] This would have a bearing on issues such as whether there had been dissipation of matrimonial assets, the Husband’s financial capacity to pay for child maintenance, and whether there were any other undisclosed bank accounts or credit cards in the Husband’s name.

11     For the reasons set out above, the Wife’s request in Items 1 and 3 is allowed.

12     Item 2 was a request for the Husband to “state and explain the sum(s) of monies” which he had allegedly loaned to his helper, and to provide details of when such loans had been disbursed and what was the outstanding sum loaned to date.

13     The basis for the Husband’s objection is that a voluntary request had not first been served. Mr Chan does not dispute that no voluntary request had been served. He explained that the Wife had taken such a course of action in a bid to avoid protracting proceedings.

14     Notwithstanding the fact that a voluntary request for Item 2 had not first been served, I am still minded to deal with the Wife’s request on its merits, though I would add that the failure to comply with the applicable rules of procedure may be a relevant consideration when it comes to costs.

15     I find that Item 2 is indeed relevant and necessary to the hearing of the ancillary matters. The quantum of the loan which the Husband had extended to their helper certainly goes towards the determination of the matrimonial pool of assets.

16     As a final point, I note that the Wife did, in fact, ask the Husband in her voluntary request for discovery, to disclose documents showing payments made to their helper. The Husband had provided a rather detailed explanation as to why such payments were made and why such payments were no longer reflected on the relevant bank statements. The Husband’s explanation, however, does not state the sums which he had loaned to the helper, and the outstanding sums that are still owed to him.[note: 3] These are all pertinent points that would have a bearing on the issues at the hearing of the ancillary matters.

17     The Wife’s request in Item 2 is allowed.

18     I come now to the final request in Item 4. This was the request as framed:

The Defendant is to state and confirm whether the flat in Seoul, South Korea at [XXX] is the only South Korean property he and his parents own and have ever owned, and if not, the address and particulars of ownership of any other property owned by the Defendant or his parents.

19     Although it is undisputed that a voluntary request in respect of this item had not been served, as I had stated above (at [14]), I am not minded to dismiss the Wife’s request on that basis. In my judgment, this interrogatory is certainly relevant and necessary to the hearing of the ancillary matters – any properties in the Husband’s name, or that are being held on the Husband’s behalf are certainly a relevant consideration when it comes to determining the matrimonial pool of assets as well as the division of such assets.

20     The Wife’s request in Item 4 is allowed.

Wife’s Application for Discovery

21     I come now to the items which the Wife had sought in discovery. In considering the Wife’s application, I bear in mind the principles that govern the discovery process, namely, that the court will only order discovery if the documents sought are relevant and necessary to the hearing of the ancillary matters: WWS v WWT [2024] SGFC 24 at [22].

22     During the hearing, Mr Chan confirmed that the Wife was not pursuing her request in respect of Items 4, 9, and 11. I shall deal with the rest of the items in turn. I will also make brief mention of Item 9 given the points that were raised by both Mr Chan and Ms Lim at the hearing before me.

23     Item 1 was a request for the Husband to produce documents showing the disbursements, transactions and purpose of loans taken from January 2023 to date.

24     The Husband does not dispute the relevance or the necessity of these documents. Rather, his position is that he has no such documents in his possession, custody or power.

25     As I had noted in WWS v WWT [2024] SGFC 24 at [75], parties cannot “tiptoe around” their obligation to give discovery with the mere assertion that they do not have the documents which are requested for. The Husband cannot sidestep his obligation to provide disclosure with the bare assertion that he has no such documents in his possession, custody or power.

26     I will allow the Wife’s request in Item 1. If the Husband says that he does not have these documents, he must provide an explanation on affidavit, and exhibit any supporting documents.

27     Item 2 was a request for documents showing the current whereabouts and purpose of various recurring withdrawals from the Husband’s HSBC account ending -21. This mirrored Item 1 of the Wife’s request for interrogatories (see above at [8(a)]).

28     I will allow the Wife’s request in Item 2 for the same reasons which I had set out above (at [10]). Although Ms Lim urged me to disallow the Wife’s request in respect of this item on the account that the sums in question were insubstantial, and that the process of discovery and interrogatories should not be used as a tool to aid in a forensic accounting exercise, as I have explained, the documents sought would cast light on why the Husband had continued to incur these expenses in the UK although parties were no longer living there.

29     Item 3 was a request for documents showing that the Husband had temporarily borrowed a sum of $2000 from one [K] on 26 June 2023, the whereabouts of this sum, and the purpose of the alleged loan.[note: 4]

30     The Husband’s basis for objecting to this request was that he had already provided all the documents in his possession, custody and power. He states that there was no written documentation in relation to these loans which were extended to him by friends.[note: 5]

31     The Wife, on the other hand, argues that disclosure should be ordered because the Husband has repeatedly made claims that various deposits and withdrawals from his bank accounts are loans/repayment of loans, but did not provide any supporting documents to back up his assertions.[note: 6] During the hearing, Mr Chan emphasised the point in his oral submissions that if these were indeed loans made from the Husband’s friends, there would be some messages to evidence such an arrangement. In this connection, these messages would go towards establishing the liabilities which the Husband now claims to have.

32     I note that the Husband’s explanation, that this transaction was repayment of a loan given to him by [K], was his response to the Wife’s voluntary request for discovery. It is a bare explanation. The Husband simply stated that it was a temporary loan from [K] made on 26 June 2023. He did not state any reasons as to why he could not produce the requested documents, neither did he state that he did not have any documents in his possession, custody or power given the nature of the loan.

33     In the circumstances, I will allow the request in respect of Item 3. The documents are, in my judgment, certainly relevant and necessary. It would go towards assessing whether this transaction was indeed for the repayment of the loan as the Husband alleges.

34     I come now to Items 5 and 6. I shall deal with them together as they both concern various deposits which had been made to the Husband’s UOB account ending -8. These were the specific requests as framed:

(a)     Item 5 was a request for documents to show that various deposits into the Husband’s UOB account ending -8 was for alleged “loans” extended to him for his living expenses and legal fees.

(b)     Item 6 was a request for documents showing the source as well as the purpose of various deposits made by certain individuals into the Husband’s UOB account ending -8.

35     The Husband objects to both Items 5 and 6 on the same basis as Item 3 – that he had already disclosed all the documents in his possession, custody and power, and that because these were loans which had been extended to him by family and friends, there was no documentation of any such loan agreements.

36     The Wife’s argument in respect of Items 5 and 6 was that that these were rather substantial deposits to the Husband’s UOB account. Accordingly, these documents would establish whether they were indeed loans extended to the Husband, or proceeds from any other sources of income or funds that the Husband had yet to disclose. This would have a bearing on issues such as determining the matrimonial pool of assets, the division of matrimonial assets and the Husband’s ability to pay maintenance.[note: 7]

37     Again, I note that in the Husband’s response to the Wife’s voluntary request for the same documents as set out in Items 5 and 6,[note: 8] he explained that these were “monies loaned” to allow him to pay for his living expenses and legal fees in Singapore and that there were “no documents for the said loans” “save for those already previously provided”. The Husband merely asserts that there are no documents, but does not go on to explain why that is the case.

38     In my judgment, both Items 5 and 6 are certainly relevant and necessary to the hearing of the ancillary matters. It would allow the court to assess the source of these deposits into the Husband’s account and the reasons for these deposits. This would, as Mr Chan had rightly pointed out in written submissions (see above at [36]), have a bearing on issues such as ascertaining the matrimonial pool of assets and maintenance.

39     The Wife’s request in both Items 5 and 6 are allowed.

40     I turn now to Item 7. This was a request for the Husband to produce documents showing the source of funds and the purpose for various deposits from company [T] to the Husband’s UOB account ending -8.

41     Again, the Husband objects to this request on the basis that he had already provided all the documents in his possession, custody and power.[note: 9] He says that these were loans extended to him by his family which had been transferred to him via a wire transfer service provider which was reflected as company [T] on his bank statements.

42     The Wife, on the other hand, argues that these documents are relevant to showing the source of such funds which are relevant to issues such as ascertaining the pool of matrimonial assets, whether there had been dissipation of any matrimonial assets and maintenance.[note: 10]

43     I agree with the arguments advanced by the Wife – these documents would show the source of the funds, and would, accordingly, shed light on the Husband’s true financial capacity and whether these were indeed, as he says, loans extended to him by his family. This would go towards issues such as ascertaining the matrimonial pool of assets as well as maintenance.

44     The Wife’s request in Item 7 is allowed.

45     Item 8 was a request for documents showing the current whereabouts and purpose of several recurring transactions from the Husband’s HSBC premier account ending -1. This request mirrored the Wife’s request for interrogatories at Item 3 (see above at [8(b)]).

46     Given that I had allowed the Wife’s request for interrogatories, I will also allow this request for discovery. The Husband shall answer the Wife’s interrogatory as framed in Item 3 and provide the relevant documents requested. In my judgment, these documents sought are indeed relevant and necessary to the hearing of the ancillary matters – they would cast light on why the Husband had, by his account,[note: 11] continued to pay for bills incurred in the UK although the family had since relocated to Singapore.

47     Item 9 was a request for documents showing the source of funds and purpose of some 21 deposits into the Husband’s HSBC premier account ending -1.

48     During the hearing, Mr Chan explained that the Wife was no longer pursuing Item 9 given the Husband’s response in his reply affidavit to SUM 3472. That being said, the Husband had also disclosed the existence of two other credit cards which he had not previously disclosed. Given this, the Wife now wanted the statements of these credit cards.

49     Ms Lim, naturally, objected to this. She said that the Wife was now shifting the goalposts of her application.

50     I did not think that this was necessarily the case. As I had explained to Ms Lim during the hearing, my understanding was that the Wife was merely seeking further discovery of the statements of these two credit cards which had now surfaced.

51     In any event, even if Mr Chan was asking that I order the disclosure of these two credit card statements, I was not minded to consider the request given that it was not included in SUM 3472, and the Husband did not appear to have had the opportunity to consider the request. In the circumstances, I directed that any further voluntary request for interrogatories and discovery be filed and served by 27 January 2025. The Husband was to give his response by 17 February 2025. I also further directed parties to attend at a Case Conference after 17 February 2025 to update the court on the status of the voluntary request and whether a formal application would be required.

52     I come now to the final request in Item 10. This was a request for documents showing that the Husband had received retrenchment benefits as well as 3 months’ worth of salary in lieu of notice. These sums of money had allegedly been paid to the Husband’s HSBC Singapore account in May 2022.

53     The Husband argues that the Wife’s request should be disallowed. He says that he had already obtained the relevant bank statement, and sought the Wife’s consent to file a further affidavit to SUM 3472 to exhibit this statement. However, the Wife did not reply. As such, this bank statement was annexed to his written submissions.[note: 12]

54     During the course of the hearing, Mr Chan argued that the sums which the Husband alleges had been paid to him as part of his retrenchment package does not match that in the bank statement which the Husband had belatedly disclosed. The Wife was therefore maintaining her request in Item 10, and sought a court order for the Husband to produce these documents.

55     It appears that the Wife is continuing the maintain her request in Item 10 because of the discrepancy between the bank statement the Husband had produced, and what he had previously declared. However, the discovery and interrogatory process is not an avenue for parties to ventilate arguments on where the truth may lie in relation to matters which are in dispute. Given that the Husband has produced a bank statement that appears to reflect the deposit of his retrenchment benefits, I make no order in relation to Item 10. I will, however, order the Husband to exhibit this bank statement in his compliance affidavit.

56     In summary, I make the following orders:

(a)     The Husband shall answer the interrogatories as set out in Items 1 – 4 of the Request for Interrogatories (as indicated at para 2b of SUM 3472) on affidavit, to the best of his knowledge, information and belief, pursuant to Rule 69 of the Family Justice Rules 2014.

(b)     The Husband shall state on affidavit, pursuant to Rule 63 of the Family Justice Rules 2014, in respect of each of the following documents listed in Items 1, 2, 3, 5, 6, 7, and 8 of the Request for Discovery (as indicated at para 1b of SUM 3472), whether the same is in his possession, custody or power, and if not then in his possession, custody or power, when he parted with it and what has become of it;

(c)     The Husband shall exhibit, in the affidavit, a copy of each of the documents that are in his possession, custody or power. If any of the documents are not in his custody, power or possession, he is to state the reasons why, together with supporting documentation for his explanation (if any).

(d)     The Husband shall also exhibit, in his compliance affidavit, the bank statement contained in Annex A of his Written Submissions dated 10 January 2025.

(e)     In addition, the Husband’s compliance affidavit is to be filed by 24 February 2025.

57     Unless parties are able to agree on costs of SUM 3472, they are to write in, by way of letter, with their respective submissions on costs. This is to be done no later than 14 February 2025 and the length of these submissions shall not exceed 3 pages.

58     For the avoidance of doubt, nothing I have said here shall bind the judge hearing the ancillary matters. The time limited for filing an appeal shall also begin to run from the date of this judgment.

59     Finally, it remains for me to thank Mr Chan and Ms Lim for their able assistance.
