XGI v XGJ

XGI v XGJ
[2025] SGFC 5

Case Number:Divorce No 4676 of 2023 (Summons No 3168 of 2024)
Decision Date:06 January 2025
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Soh Kian Peng
Counsel Name(s): Gurmeet Kaur d/o Amar Singh (Harjeet Singh & Co) for the plaintiff; Arul Suppiah Thevar (APL Law Corporation) for the defendant.
Parties: XGI — XGJ

Family Law – Costs

6 January 2025

Judgment reserved

Assistant Registrar Soh Kian Peng:

1       This is my decision on the costs of SUM 3168/2024 (“SUM 3168”). That summons had been taken out by the Wife who sought leave to file a joint affidavit from her four daughters to address issues relating to certain items of gold jewellery. My decision in respect of SUM 3168 can be found in XGI v XGJ [2024] SGFC 110.

2       These were the parties’ respective submissions on the issue of costs.

3       The Husband’s position was that the issue of costs should be addressed at the hearing of the ancillary matters. In any case, parties should bear their own costs as they are both legally aided.

4       On the other hand, the Wife’s position was that, although both parties were legally aided, the Husband should still be liable for costs, to the tune of $2500, pursuant to s 14(3)(b) of the Legal Aid and Advice Act 1995 (“LAA”) as he had acted improperly in resisting her application in SUM 3168. These costs should be paid to the Director of Legal Aid.

5       Where costs are sought against legally aided persons, there are two relevant provisions (WXG v WXH [2024] SGFC 41). The first is s 12(4)(c) of the LAA which states:

(4)    Where any Grant of Aid is so filed, the aided person —

(c)    is not, except where express provision is made in this Act, liable for costs to any other party in any proceedings to which the Grant of Aid relates; and

6       The second is s 14 of the LAA. That provision states:

Court may order payment of costs by aided person in certain event

14.—(1)    Where it appears to a court that any of the circumstances mentioned in subsection (3) exists in relation to an aided person, the court may order the aided person to pay the costs of all or any of the following persons:

(a)    the Director;

(b)    the solicitor who acted for the aided person;

(c)    the other party.

(2)    In subsection (1), a reference to an “aided person” includes, in any case where the Grant of Aid has been cancelled before the making of the order, the person who immediately before the cancellation was the aided person.

(3)    For the purposes of subsection (1), the circumstances are as follows:

(a)    the Grant of Aid issued to the aided person has been obtained by fraud or misrepresentation;

(b)    the aided person acted improperly in bringing or defending any legal proceedings, or in the conduct of those proceedings.

(4)    Where an order is made under subsection (1), the costs must be taxed as if the party ordered to pay costs were not an aided person.

(5)    The costs so ordered to be paid must, unless otherwise directed by the order, include —

(a)    fees and charges of the nature referred to in section 12(4)(a) and (b); and

(b)    any sums which, pursuant to section 13(3), were expended by the Director in meeting out-of-pocket expenses or were advanced by the Director for that purpose.

(6)    Where the costs of the Director or the solicitor who acted for the aided person ordered to be paid under subsection (1) include any of the fees, charges or sums referred to in subsection (5), then if any amount is recovered by the Director in respect of such costs, the same must be applied in the first instance in or towards the satisfaction of such fees, charges or sums.

7       Given that the Wife is invoking s 14(3)(b) to argue that the Husband should be liable for costs despite being legally aided, she bears the burden of showing that the Husband had acted improperly in resisting her application in SUM 3168. In that vein, the mere fact that the Husband did not prevail in his bid to have SUM 3168 dismissed is not, in of itself, evidence that he had acted improperly. The Wife must put forward evidence to show that the Husband had conducted his “defence in a way that a reasonable [respondent] would not”: Anpex Pte Ltd v Cheng Yong Sun and another [2022] SGHC 294 at [4].

8       The Wife’s basis for saying that the Husband had acted improperly in resisting her application in SUM 3168 appears to be that the Husband was lying in his affidavits when it came to the issue of the gold jewellery. The Wife points out that in his first Affidavit of Assets and Means, he had alleged that the jewellery was removed by the Wife from the matrimonial flat, and that the jewellery had been acquired during the course of their marriage.[note: 1] The Husband, however, appears to shift his position because in a Reply Affidavit filed later on the 12th of November 2024, he denied the “existence and/or true value of the…gold jewellery items” which had been purchased by the Wife and their children.[note: 2]

9       In the circumstances, the costs of SUM 3168 shall be reserved to the judge hearing the ancillary matters. It is apparent to me that the issue of whether the Husband had acted improperly in resisting the Wife’s application is linked to the issue of who had bought and paid for the gold jewellery, as well as the truth of whatever the Husband had said in the various affidavits he had filed. These are matters to be decided by the judge hearing the ancillary matters, and the judge’s findings in respect of these issues may have a bearing on whether the Husband had indeed acted improperly in resisting the Wife’s application in SUM 3168.

10     As a final point, and for the avoidance of doubt, nothing I have said here shall bind the hands of the judge hearing the ancillary matters.

[note: 1]Wife’s Submissions on Costs at para 7.

[note: 2]Wife’s Submissions on Costs at para 5.

XER v XES

XER v XES
[2025] SGFC 4

Case Number:FC/D No. 1721 of 2023 (FC/SUM No. 2056 of 2024)
Decision Date:06 January 2025
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Kow Keng Siong
Counsel Name(s): Pang Khin Wee (M/s I.R.B. Law LLP) for the Father; Dylan Han Yong Ding & Angelina Hing Wei Yuen (M/s Integro Law Chambers) for the Mother.
Parties: XER — XES

Family Law – Procedure – Costs – Applicant seeking costs on the basis that he had been partially successful in his application to vary orders relating to his daughter’s care and control and access

Family Law – Procedure – Costs – Respondent seeking costs on the basis that the applicant had acted unreasonably by failing to resolve the issues amicably without the need for litigation

Family Law – Procedure – Costs – Approach to awarding costs in matrimonial proceedings

6 January 2025

District Judge Kow Keng Siong:

Introduction

1       To re-cap –

(a)     In Summons 2056 of 2024 (“SUM 2056”), the Father had applied to vary the Daughter’s care and access arrangements made in an order on ancillary matters.

(b)     In XER v XES [2024] SGFC 98 (“Judgement”), I had made the following decision regarding the Father’s application:

Prayer

Nature of application

Outcome

3

To switch the Daughter’s caregiver from the Mother to the Father.

Dismissed

4 and 5

To allow the Father to carry out the access in the presence of non-family members.

Allowed in part

6

To increase the number of ways in which the Daughter was to be handed over to the Father for access.

Allowed in part



Summary of parties’ position

2       After my decision, the parties made the following submissions on costs. (For more details, see Annex A.)

 

Father’s submissions

Mother’s submissions

(a)

The Father should be given costs because he has succeeded in SUM 2056.[note: 1]

The Mother should be given costs because the Father is “completely unsuccessful” in his application.[note: 2]

(b)

It is reasonable for the Father to commence SUM 2056 without first attempting to resolve the dispute out of court.

The issues in SUM 2056 could have been resolved much earlier without the need for litigation.

(c)

The Father should be awarded costs (at $3,000), disbursements (at $250) and GST.

The Mother should be awarded costs (at $12,000) and disbursements (at $514.50).



My decision

3       After considering the matter, I award costs in favour of the Mother at $6,500 (inclusive of disbursements). In this judgement, I will explain the reasons for my decision.

Applicable principles

4       I begin by setting out the applicable principles. They are as follows:

(a)      Starting position. Under of the Family Justice Rules 2014 (“FJR”), the starting position is that “costs should follow the event” – i.e., in usual cases, the successful party should be given the costs of the application or action: r 852(2).

(b)      Therapeutic justice. However, the FJR also provides that a court is free to depart from the starting position if the “circumstances of the case” warrant it: r 852(2). In this regard, courts frequently decline to make costs orders at the end of matrimonial proceedings: JBB v JBA [2015] 5 SLR 153 (“JBB”) at [24] to [27]. There are at least two reasons for this. First, it is often hard to say which party has “succeeded” in such proceedings. Second, a costs order may also be perceived as a signal that one party has “won” and the other has “lost”. Courts prefer not to send such a signal as this may increase acrimony and discontent between the parties – and thus undermine the aims of therapeutic justice.

(c)      Parties’ conduct. The judicial preference of not ordering costs does not mean that costs orders will never be made in matrimonial proceedings.

(i)       This is because when determining whether there is a need to make costs orders, courts are statutorily obliged to consider the parties’ conduct before and during the proceedings. This includes considering whether they have made any attempt to resolve their dispute: r 854 of the FJR (“must”).

(ii)       In this regard, a court “may” make a costs order, including against a successful party, if a party “has failed to establish any claim or issue which he has raised”, and “has thereby unnecessarily or unreasonably protracted or added to the costs or complexity [of the proceedings]”: r 865 of the FJR.

(iii)       Courts have held that a costs order would be justified –

(1)       Where one party had made a genuine and reasonable offer to settle the matrimonial proceedings, and the matter could have been settled without the need for litigation: WLL v WLM [2023] SGHCF 30 at [7], or

(2)       To signal that the adversarial stance taken by a party is not acceptable in a family justice system that adopts therapeutic justice: VVB v VVA [2022] 4 SLR 1181 at [26] and [28].

(d)     To sum up – it is appropriate to make costs orders to deter conduct which is contrary to the principles of therapeutic justice. If the appropriate signal is not sent, then parties who act reasonably may feel exploited by those who do not subscribe to such principles. Over time, confidence in the practice of therapeutic justice will be eroded and this is detrimental to our family justice system.

Costs ought to be ordered against the Father

5       Following from [4] above, whether the Father has succeeded in part, or has been “completely unsuccessful” in SUM 2056 is not determinative of whether costs should be ordered: see [2(a)] above.

6       Instead, the more pertinent issue is whether the Father’s or the Mother’s conduct of SUM 2056 warrants a costs order against him/her: JBB at [33].

7       On this issue, I find that a costs order should be made against the Father. Let me explain.

Prayers 1 and 2 – Sale of matrimonial flat

8       I begin with Prayers 1 and 2. They are the Father’s application –

(a)     for extension of time to sell the matrimonial flat: Prayer 1;

(b)     to have sole conduct of such a sale: Prayer 2.

9        Father’s allegations. To support these prayers, the Father alleged the following in an affidavit dated 30 August 2024:[note: 3]

36.    There is currently no confirmation when such completion will be, if at all. There is a chance that the completion may eventually be called off given the current buyer’s increasing financial penalties for delaying completion.

37.    It is now 30 August 2024, and the Matrimonial Flat’s completion is still being delayed indefinitely.

38.    Parties thus now require an extension of time for the sale of the Matrimonial Flat.

[emphasis added]

10     The above allegations give the impression that as of 30 August 2024 –

(a)     The completion for the sale of the flat had been delayed indefinitely.

(b)     The Father did not have any confirmation as to when the completion would take place.

(c)     He did not know if the completion would ever happen.

11      Allegations are false. The Father’s allegations are clearly false given the following undisputed evidence:

(a)     In a letter dated 21 August 2024 (i.e., nine days before the Father’s affidavit was filed), HDB had already written to the Mother and him to confirm the following:[note: 4]

(i)       The “effective date for resale” of the flat “has been fixed on 30/8/2024” (underscore in original text, italics added).

(ii)       The Father and the Mother were to pay the flat’s “service/conservancy charges up to 30/08/24” with the town council.

(iii)       “[T]here should be no outstanding service/conservancy and lift upgrading charges due to the Town Council on the resale effective date”.

(b)     There is no suggestion that the completion date of 30 August 2024 would be postponed. In fact, in so far as HDB is concerned, the completion was to proceed as scheduled. This is clear from two letters (dated 22 August 2024) which HDB had sent to the parties. In these letters, HDB specifically informed them of the following:[note: 5]

(i)       The parties had to pay $38,886.68 to settle the completion of account for the resale of the flat.

(ii)       “The completion of the resale transaction has been scheduled for you to sign the legal documents and hand over the keys to the flat”. (emphasis added)

(iii)       The completion would be on 30 August 2024 at 3.30 pm at the HDB Hub, Resale Office. (emphasis added)

(c)     It is clear that the Father and the Mother had no intention to postpone the completion date of 30 August 2024. In a document dated 22 August 2024, the Father had confirmed with HDB that the Mother and he “will handover the house keys as there are no extension of stay”.[note: 6]

(d)     There is also no evidence to show that the buyer(s) had between 21 to 30 August 2024 asked to postpone the completion fixed on 30 August 2024.

(e)     The completion eventually proceeded on 30 August 2024.

12      Father’s position on the false allegations. The Father denied that the allegations were false.

(a)     His counsel submitted unconvincingly that (i) the Father’s allegations referred to the “actual act of completion where parties sign all the documents and complete the transaction”, and (ii) 30 August 2024 was only the “anticipated completion date”.

(b)     The Father’s counsel also submitted that the allegations were merely “outdated” and not false. To support this submission, counsel stated that the Father’s affidavit was confirmed on 29 August 2024 and signed in the morning of 30 August 2024 – i.e., before the completion.

(c)     I find these submissions to be disingenuous.

(i)        First, the Father could have waited until after 3.30 pm (i.e., the scheduled completion time) to file his affidavit. If the completion did not proceed as scheduled, he could then state this accordingly in his affidavit.

(ii)        Second, based on the eLit records, the Father’s affidavit was filed only at 5.42 pm – i.e., two hours after the time fixed for the completion.

(iii)        Finally, after the completion of the flat, the Father would have known that (1) the completion had concluded successfully and (2) the evidence/impression which he had conveyed in [9] and [10] are “erroneous” (to use counsel’s description). During the hearing, the Father’s counsel agreed that a reasonable person would have taken steps to correct this “error” – e.g., by expeditiously informing his counsel to clarify the matter during the case conference on 10 September 2024 or by filing a supplemental affidavit. The Father had failed to do so.

13      Unnecessary work done. As a result of the Father’s conduct (false allegations and failure to correct them), the Mother had to seek the leave of court to file a further affidavit to clarify that the flat had already been sold. This affidavit was filed on 17 September 2024. It was only after this further affidavit that the Father’s counsel informed the Mother’s counsel that Prayers 1 and 2 would be withdrawn. This took place only on 23 September 2024 – i.e., about three weeks after the completion of the resale of the matrimonial flat. By then, unnecessary work has been done by the Wife and her counsel to address Prayers 1 and 2. The Father’s conduct is clearly unacceptable.

Prayer 3 – Variation of Daughter’s caregiver

14     Next, I turn to Prayer 3 of SUM 2056, which is the Father’s application to replace the Mother as the Daughter’s caregiver. By way of a quick re-cap, the Father had made the application on two grounds. First, he had discovered his Daughter’s photos on social media which show her to be in an allegedly inappropriate pose and in the company of “strangers”. According to the Father, this showed that the Mother had failed to protect the Daughter’s interests. Second, he alleged that the Mother had denied him access to the Daughter: Judgement at [12] and [14].

15     I dismissed Prayer 3 because I found it to be dubious and “utterly devoid of merit”: Judgement at [23] to [35]. There is no evidence to show that the Father had approached the Mother to clarify matters before seeking this prayer. In my view, he could have addressed his concerns expeditiously and easily by simply checking with the Mother.

Prayers 4 and 5 – Variation of non-family members clause

16     I now turn to Prayers 4 and 5. The Father had wanted the following clause to be completely deleted from the AM Order.[note: 7]

Plaintiff’s access shall not be in the presence of non-family members.

17     The Mother objected to the complete deletion of this clause because she was concerned for the Daughter’s safety if she was with strangers. The Mother was however prepared to be flexible, and she proposed the following variation to the non-family members clause:[note: 8]

Save for the Plaintiff’s romantic partner, the The Plaintiff’s access shall not be in the presence of non-family members, unless the Plaintiff obtains the Defendant’s prior consent in writing.

18     I note that as early as 2 August 2024, the Mother had already proposed her variation in [17] to the Father in her Offer To Settle (“OTS”). The Father did not accept the offer. Neither did he attempt to address the Mother’s concerns, e.g., by counter-proposing suitable text. It is the Father’s case that he did not trust her enough to negotiate on a mutually acceptable access clause.

19     I agree with the Mother that Prayers 4 and 5 could have been resolved much earlier if the Father had adopted a problem-solving approach and proposed modifications to the Mother’s OTS.[note: 9] Indeed, I had noted that –

… during the proceedings, the Father had largely stuck to his positions and did not make much effort to address the Mother’s concerns arising from his application. In contrast, in line with the spirit of therapeutic justice, the Mother had shown flexibility and reasonableness – e.g., by suggesting suitable language for varying the access orders.[note: 10]

20     I eventually varied the non-family members’ clause as follows:

The Plaintiff’s access shall not be in the presence of non-family members save for the following circumstances:

(i)     The non-family member is the Plaintiff’s romantic partner.

(ii)    The presence of the non-family member is incidental to the Child pursuing her recreational, educational, or other needs during the access periods.

If the Plaintiff wishes to conduct the access in the presence of non-family members in other circumstances, then he must seek the Defendant’s prior consent in writing.

[variation in underscore] [bolding added]

21     Although I had eventually allowed Prayers 4 and 5, the following bears highlighting.

(a)      First, the Mother’s variations and the ones that I have ordered are substantively similar, save the text in bold.

(b)      Second, the Father did not make any contribution towards the formulation of the varied clause that I have ordered.

Prayer 6 – Modes of child access

22     Finally, I come to Prayer 6. In this prayer, the Father had sought to expand the manner in which he could exercise access to the Daughter. I had found the Father’s proposed variations in Prayer 6 to be “problematic”.[note: 11]

23     I eventually accepted the Mother’s proposed variations which, in my view, “strikes the right balance between flexibility and certainty regarding the manner of the handover”.[note: 12]

24     The Mother’s proposed variations are not new – she had already proposed them to the Father in her OTS in August 2024. In my view, it is unreasonable for him to reject the Mother’s proposed variations. Litigation on Prayer 6 could have been avoided.

Summing-up

25     To sum-up, I agree with the Mother that in relation to the issues in SUM 2056, valuable time and resources have been wasted because of the Father’s uncompromising stance, even when she had made a reasonable OTS. The Father has failed to substantiate his bare allegation that “it was reasonable for [him] to not try to negotiate further with the [Mother]” at the material time.[note: 13]

26     The Father cannot continue with such an attitude. The Daughter is only eight years old. For the next 13 years, he will need to work together with the Mother on matters relating to their Daughter.

27     In my view, it is necessary to make a costs order against the Father to clearly signal to him that he needs to be more reasonable moving forward, and to compensate the Mother for the costs that she had unnecessarily incurred in the Father’s pursuit of SUM 2056.[note: 14]

Amount of costs

28     In my view, an order of $6,500 (all in) would be appropriate in this case. In coming to this amount, I have considered (a) the extent of work done, and (b) the fact that the Mother had shown flexibility in trying to resolve the issues early – by making an OTS and through the facilitative conduct of her counsel during the hearing.

29     The terms of the OTS are substantially similar to those that I have ordered. Admittedly, the Mother’s proposal regarding the non-family members clause did not go far enough: Judgement at [48] and [49]. That said, I do not think that this is due to a lack of genuine efforts on her part to resolve the access issue. I am satisfied that her OTS was made in good faith. If only the Father had kept an open mind and proposed suitable language to the non-family members’ clause to address the Mother’s concern, the issue could have been resolved with the need for litigation.

30     The Father is to pay $6,500 to DBS Account No. 014-904xx by 27 February 2025.

Conclusion

31     Before concluding, I wish to make a few observations.

32      First, to support his claim that it was not reasonable for him to negotiate with the Mother, the Father submitted that after my decision on Prayers 4 and 5, the Wife had refused to allow him to bring the Daughter to visit his partner’s family members for Deepavali celebrations.[note: 15]

33     I am unable to accept the Father’s submissions.

(a)     To support his submissions, the Father had relied on his chat records with the Mother. I find that these records are not admissible – they are annexed to the Father’s submissions and are not adduced by way of affidavit.

(b)     Furthermore, the Mother’s counsel submitted that the Father had omitted the rest of the parties’ conversation, and that there was no evidence that the Daughter could not visit his partner’s family members for Deepavali celebrations. It is the Mother’s case that after my variations on the relevant clauses, the Father’s child access has proceeded smoothly. She is prepared to adduce the relevant evidence to support her case.[note: 16]

34      Second, my decision in this case seeks to emphasise the point that the practice of therapeutic justice is not merely a vague concept. It is a key principle in our family justice system, with real practical implications on how parties are expected to resolve their matrimonial disputes.

__________________________

ANNEX A

DETAILS OF PARTIES’ SUBMISSIONS

 

Father’s submissions

Mother’s submissions

1

Outcome of SUM 2056

 

The Father’s “main point” is that he has succeeded in part for Prayers 4 and 5, as well as Prayer 6.[note: 17]

The Father is “completely unsuccessful” in SUM 2056.[note: 18] Out of the six prayers, two were withdrawn (Prayers 1 and 2), one was dismissed (Prayer 3), and three were allowed in part (Prayers 4 – 6).[note: 19]

2

Was it necessary to commence SUM 2056

 

Yes –

(a) Prayers 3 to 7 – These were granted in part. In other words, the Father’s application was necessary to begin with.[note: 20]

(b) Prayers 4 and 5 – The Mother’s counterproposals did not go far enough as they were impractical and/or could unwittingly lead to misunderstanding and friction between the parties.[note: 21]

No –

(a) The prayers sought by the Father are completely different from the orders made.[note: 22]

(b) Prayer 3 – The Father did not raise this in his OTS, and the issue was not discussed with Mother.[note: 23]

(c) Prayers 4 and 5 – The court largely agreed with the Mother’s proposal and made an order that extended her proposal. These prayers could have been resolved much earlier if the Father had proposed. further modifications which the Mother could agree to.[note: 24]

(d) Prayer 6 – The court’s order is identical to her proposal.[note: 25]

(e) SUM 2056 could have been resolved much earlier.[note: 26] The Mother has taken the same position in her OTS and her affidavit regarding her proposed variations.

3

Should the Father have negotiated with the Mother

 

No –

(a) It is reasonable for the Father “to not try to negotiate further with the [Mother]”.[note: 27] He had good reasons for disbelieving that the Mother would act in good faith.[note: 28]

(b) Even after the judgement, the Mother is still refusing to allow the Father to bring the Daughter to visit his partner’s family members for Deepavali celebrations. This is despite the court’s ruling that the Father’s access may be in the presence of non-family members if it is incidental to the Child “pursuing her recreational […] or other needs during the access periods”.[note: 29]

Yes –

(a) It is unreasonable for the Father to simply stick to his positions and refuse to negotiate any of his prayers. This resulted in a contested hearing.[note: 30]

(b) The Father’s submissions that the Mother continues to frustrate his child access should be disregarded. First, he relies on chat records between the parties to support his claim that she had refused to allow him to bring the Daughter to visit his partner’s family members for Deepavali celebrations. These records should not be accorded any weight because they were not exhibited in any affidavit. Second, there is no evidence that the Father was unable to bring the Daughter to visit his partner’s family members for Deepavali celebrations. He had omitted the rest of the parties’ conversation. Third, the Father’s access has proceeded smoothly. The Mother is prepared to adduce evidence proving the abovementioned matters, if the Honourable Court requires.[note: 31]



[note: 1]See Plaintiff’s Written Submissions dated 22 November 2024 at [7] and [14]; Plaintiff’s Written Submissions dated 17 December 2024 at [32] and [34].

[note: 2]See Defendant Mother’s Written Submissions on Costs dated 22 November 2024 at [5(a)], [7] and [8].

[note: 3]Father’s affidavit dated 30 August 2024.

[note: 4]Mother’s affidavit dated 17 September 2024 at page 8; Defendant Mother’s Written Submissions on Costs dated 22 November 2024 at [33].

[note: 5]Mother’s affidavit dated 17 September 2024 at pages 10 and 13; Defendant Mother’s Written Submissions on Costs dated 22 November 2024 at [33].

[note: 6]Mother’s affidavit dated 17 September 2024 at page 17.

[note: 7]For the Father’s reasons for the variation, see Judgement at [38] to [40].

[note: 8]For further details, see Judgement at [41] to [43].

[note: 9]Defendant Mother’s Written Submissions on Costs dated 22 November 2024 at [15].

[note: 10]Judgement at [62].

[note: 11]Judgement at [59].

[note: 12]Judgement at [60].

XGU v XGV

XGU v XGV
[2024] SGFC 114

Case Number:Originating Summons (Guardianship of Infants Act) No 64 of 2024
Decision Date:06 January 2025
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Marcus Ho
Counsel Name(s): Quek Liuyong Uthai (I.R.B Law LLP) for the Plaintiff; Defendant in person.
Parties: XGU — XGV

Family Law – Custody – Care and control – Access

Family Law – Guardianship of Infants Act – Welfare of child

6 January 2025

District Judge Marcus Ho:

Introduction

1       This was an application filed by the Plaintiff Father, who sought various orders relating to the child of the marriage, including orders for sole care and control and an order to produce the child before the Court. Having considered parties’ evidence and submissions, I made various orders relating to the child’s care arrangements, including an order for the Defendant Mother to have sole care and control of the child, and orders providing for the Father’s access to the Child. The Father has since appealed against the whole of my decision. I now set out herein the reasons for my decision.

Brief background

2       The parties are both Indian nationals. They married on 4 August 2017 in India. The Father is on an Employment Pass, while the Mother is on an S Pass, that was extended until 10 August 2027.[note: 1] The child of the marriage was born on 8 November 2018 (the “Child”).

3       The Father had been living in Singapore prior to the marriage. The Mother lived in India, but moved to Singapore to join the Father after the marriage. The parties lived in rental premises throughout the marriage, first in a property at Pegu Road, and thereafter in an apartment at Henderson Road, where the Father continued to live in as at the date of hearing.

4       It was not disputed that sometime in April 2023, the Mother left their rented apartment with the Child, taking the Child’s passport with her.

5       Sometime in May 2024, the Mother and the Child travelled to India. While the Mother returned to Singapore thereafter, the Child remained there, living with the Mother’s parents. The Father did not know that the Child had travelled to India or that the Child has been living there until the Mother revealed this at a Family Dispute Resolution (“FDR”) Conference on 5 August 2024.

6       On 29 May 2024, the Father filed the present application. Sometime in August 2024, the Mother filed for a divorce in Bangalore, India. In this regard, the Mother asked that the present proceedings be stayed for the court in Bangalore to determine the Child’s custody issues. As there was no application filed by the Mother to stay the present proceedings, I declined to do so, and proceeded to hear this matter on 16 October 2024.

7       Apart from the present proceedings, the parties had previously applied for a personal protection order against each other: the Mother in SS 1624/2022, and the Father in SS 635/2023. A PPO was issued in respect of SS 1624/2022, restraining the Father from committing family violence against the Mother. SS 635/2023 was dismissed.

The Father’s application

8       In his application, the Father sought the following orders:

(a)     That the Mother be restrained from removing the Child from Singapore until further orders;

(b)     That the Mother shall handover the Child’s passport to the Father’s solicitors for safekeeping, and that the Father’s solicitors shall not handover the passport to anyone until further orders;

(c)     That the Father be granted interim care and control of the Child;

(d)     That the Father be granted interim liberal access to the Child pending the resolution of the matter, or until further orders;

(e)     That the Mother produces the Child before the court within 7 days of the order.

9       Among the reasons given by the Father, the Father said that the Mother has been unduly restrictive with his access to the Child. The Father said that the Mother would make various unilateral decisions without consulting him, and suggested that she has been less than cooperative as a parent. The Father said that the Mother is unsuited to be the Child’s main caregiver because “she has no qualm [sic] in using [the Child] as a tool to control the Father and she does not care whether there is a healthy father relationship between [the Child] and [the Father]”.[note: 2] The Father said that there is a “pressing need for him to see the Child to determine if further medical care is required” in the wake of the Child’s operation in April 2024.[note: 3] The Father says that he has “suffered from being completely cut off from [the Child] since November 2023 and [he] can no longer endure it as [he] truly miss[es] [the Child] a lot”.[note: 4]

My decision

10     When faced with an application filed under Section 5 of the Guardianship and Infants Act 1934, the court is foremost guided by doing what is in the Child’s best interests. The court is less concerned about achieving equity or equality between parents. There is, after all, no standing presumption that both parents should have equal responsibility over, or equal time with, their child (see TAU v TAT [2018] 5 SLR 1089 at [12] and [20]). Each party’s behaviour toward the other, or indeed their respective contributions toward the marriage, are relevant to the extent that it affects the child in question. This may be the case where, for example, a party’s actions may have a direct or indirect impact on their ability to care for their child, or on their child’s relationship with them.

11     I therefore examined the reasons for the Father’s application, and considered, based on his reasons, how the orders sought by the Father would advance the Child’s best interests, rather than that of either party.

Care and control

12     On the evidence provided, I found some force to the Father’s arguments that the Mother had not been cooperative as a joint parent and that she had not been facilitative of the Father spending time with the Child. For instance:

(a)     From April 2023 to the time of hearing, which was a span of nearly one and a half years, the Father only met the Child once in person. This was in public, and in the Mother’s presence, at VivoCity on 8 November 2023;

(b)     Apart from this brief access in November 2023, the Father only had two video calls with the Child which lasted for about three to four minutes each;

(c)     Whereas the Child had been attending a preschool at Redhill Close, the Mother withdrew the Child on 31 December 2022 and enrolled him into a different preschool at Henderson Crescent. The Mother did not consult the Father, nor did she inform him of this before effecting the withdrawal and enrolment.

(d)     The Mother arranged for the Child to undergo an adenoidectomy in India in April 2024 without consulting or informing the Father. The Mother says that she informed the Father’s mother, but never received any queries from her or the Father. At the hearing, the Mother said that she did not think that the Father would be interested, and acknowledged that she should have informed the Father but did not.

(e)     There was evidence that even when the parties were living together, the Mother was less than forthcoming about the Child’s whereabouts. For instance, WhatsApp messages between 8 October to 29 October 2022 suggested that there were various occasions where the Father would ask to see the Child, or ask about the Child, without any response from the Mother.[note: 5] The WhatsApp messages on 21 and 22 January 2023 suggested that the Mother had taken the Child on a “stay holiday” without informing the Father. Despite the Father’s message at 8.54am on 22 January 2023 requesting the Mother to bring the Child back earlier for lunch, or for her to inform him of the Child’s whereabouts and the time they would be returning, the Mother only responded to the message at 11.47pm without providing any of the information sought, though they had yet to return at that late hour.[note: 6]

(f)     There was also some evidence that the Mother had spoken uncharitably of the Father in front of the Child. For instance, a transcript of a recorded conversation shows that the Mother told the Child that the Father “is not your father because he doesn’t take care. He is not your father. You no need to call him Abbu. He doesn’t take any responsibility.”[note: 7] At pages 168 to 169 of FA1, a transcript of another recorded conversation suggests that the Child told the Father that the Mother “threatens [the Father]” and that he is “also afraid of her”. [note: 8]

(g)     On the evidence provided, when the Father tried to initiate access, the Mother appeared slow to respond, or else did not respond at all. For instance, on 22 April 2023, the Father requested for some video call access, but the Mother did not respond to this at all. On 9 September 2023, the Father requested to see the Child at 3.00pm the next day, but the Mother only responded at 3.09pm on 10 September 2023 to say that she was unwell, after the Father sent another message at 2.37pm that day.[note: 9]

13     Taken at face value, the Mother’s actions, as described by the Father, suggest that she may have been inclined to fetter the Father’s time with the Child and to exclude him from making significant decisions relating to the Child. However, I also noted the following, which I found to have diluted the strength of the Father’s claim and reduced the culpability of the Mother’s actions:

(a)     Despite the Father’s claims that he had made multiple requests for access, I noted that there was limited evidence showing this. For instance, a screenshot of WhatsApp messages between them showed that after the Father’s request for a video call with the Child on 22 April 2023, which the Mother did not respond to, the Father did not send another message or make any other request to the Mother until 8 August 2023, when the Father requested to take the Child out for the afternoon.[note: 10] There was no evidence provided on affidavit that explained this gap in time.

(b)     Similarly, there was no evidence of the Father asking about the Child’s well-being, whether on a consistent basis or otherwise. In this regard, there appears to be some truth to the Mother’s messages sent to the Father on 10 September 2023 at 3.16pm and 3.24pm, namely that the Father only wanted to spend time with the Child at his own convenience, and that he had not been asking how the Child was doing.[note: 11] There was no evidence that the Father replied to these messages, and the Father did not provide an explanation for these messages in his affidavits.

(c)     Further, with respect to the Father’s access on 8 November 2023, the Mother’s evidence was that when they met, the Father “could not control his anger and temper and began shouting and cursing at [the Mother] in front of [the Child]”.[note: 12] This was supported by a screenshot of WhatsApp messages she had sent to the Father, recording her displeasure at how the access went. The Father did not specifically dispute this, nor did he adduce any further WhatsApp messages to refute or to provide further context to the Mother’s messages.

14     In any event, while the Father argues that the Mother’s actions may have had a consequential adverse effect on the Father’s relationship with the Child, the relationship between the parent and child is but one of the factors that the court considers in its assessment the child’s welfare (see TSF v TSE [2018] 2 SLR 833 at [51]).

15     On the balance of things, I was not persuaded that the Father should have sole care and control of the Child, as sought by him. Rather, I was of the view that the Child would benefit from continuing to reside with his primary caregiver. On the evidence, this appeared to be the Mother, not the Father:

(a)     One month after the Child was born, the Mother returned to India with the Child. The Child therefore spent his first year under the Mother’s primary care with limited physical involvement from the Father. After the Mother and the Child returned to Singapore in December 2019, there was little evidence adduced to suggest that the Father took over the role as the Child’s primary caregiver.

(b)     While the Father claimed to have been very much involved in the Child’s life, the Father’s best evidence of his involvement was that he fed his son well, took him to his favourite indoor playgrounds alone, and purchased baby supplies for him. He said that on occasion, he would “give [the Child] a shower, put on a suit, and clean his poop”, and that every time the Child was ill, he would take him to the clinic.[note: 13] The Father also pointed to his efforts in applying for a student pass for the Child, but I did not think that this necessarily indicated his level of involvement in the Child’s day to day affairs.

(c)     At paragraph 3.7 of MA1, the Mother alleged that the “only interest [the Father] showed in [the Child] was limited to taking him out to indoor playgrounds for a couple of hours over the weekend or taking him to his sister’s house in Jurong East”. The Father had the opportunity to respond to this but did not do more than make a blanket statement that “these allegations are false”.[note: 14] The Father never provided much detail as to any other activities or events he would take the Child to.

16     On the face of the evidence, I could not accept that the Father was a primary, or even an equal, caregiver during the marriage. I found that the Father likely bore the responsibility of being the main breadwinner of the family, but took on more of a supporting role when it came to parenting the Child. In contrast, the fact that the Mother was primarily responsible for caring for the Child during the marriage, as well as the Mother’s ability to physically care for the Child, were not seriously disputed. Rather, the Father’s main charge about the Mother’s suitability as a caregiver was that “the [Mother] is not a suitable caregiver to [the Child] presently given her tendency to destroy the parental link between [the Child] and [the Father]”.[note: 15]

17     I ultimately found that the Child had, throughout his life, mostly been reliant on the Mother and that it would be remiss to remove the Child from the Mother’s care. As the Child’s primary caregiver, the Mother would be better placed to attend to the Child’s physical and emotional needs, and provide the Child with a sense of stability amidst this period of transition. Further, I found that much of the Father’s concerns may be addressed through appropriate orders on custody and access, and do not in itself justify the order of sole care and control that he sought. I therefore found that the Mother should be granted sole care and control of the Child.

Access

18     With respect to the Father’s access to the Child, the Father’s position was that he should have liberal access to the Child, if care and control was not granted to him. The Mother did not object to the Father having access, but said that this should take place in India. Otherwise, any access in Singapore should be in her presence, and should not be accompanied by any other members of the Father’s family.

19     While the Mother said that the Child has been much happier in India, there was little evidence to support this. The Mother provided scant details of the Child’s routine and living arrangements to the court, and it appears that prior to the FDR Conference on 5 August 2024, the Mother did not even inform the Father of this significant development. I did not find the Mother’s decision to take the Child to Bangalore for a surgery, and then to effectively relocate the Child there, to be reasonable or justified. If this surgery was indeed necessary, I did not see why the Mother could not undergo the surgery here in Singapore. The Mother did not satisfactorily explain this (and never cited finances as a reason for doing so).

20     Further, the Mother’s case that the Child’s best interests would be best served in India was not substantiated on the evidence. The circumstances of the Mother taking the Child to India, without informing the Father and without any court application to do so, lend itself to the inference that the Mother herself may not have felt that she had such a strong case in that regard. I found the Mother’s reasons for not informing the Father of her decisions to have been unsatisfactory. I therefore did not deem it appropriate to effectively affirm the Mother’s actions by ordering any access to take place in India.

21     Rather, I found on the circumstances of the case that the Father should have regular access with the Child, and that such access should take place in Singapore. Notwithstanding the Mother’s misgivings, there is no evidence to suggest that the Father is unable to exercise access with the Child, particularly where it is not disputed that he had previously taken the Child out on his own to indoor playgrounds when the Child was younger. The Father should be given the opportunity to establish – or re-establish – his relationship with the Child, and to be the parent that the Mother says he has never been.

22     However, given the length of time since the Father had any substantial time with the Child, I was of the view that such access should be exercised on an incremental basis. I did not find the liberal access suggested by the Father to be in the Child’s best interests, and I also noted from the requests made by the Father to the Mother for access over the past one and a half years that he never asked for any overnight access with the Child, or even for a period of much longer than a few hours. As the Child has been living in India for nearly six months as at the time of the hearing, I allowed a transition period of two weeks before access was to commence.

23     I therefore ordered that the Father has reasonable access to the Child in the following terms:

(a)     For the first 6 weeks, with effect from the week commencing 25 November 2024, the Father shall spend 3 hours either on Saturday or Sunday for a meal and an activity with the Child. The Mother shall be at liberty to be present during this access;

(b)     For the next 6 weeks, and for a period of 3 months, the Father shall continue to spend 3 hours either on Saturday or Sunday for a meal and an activity with the Child. The Mother is not to be present during this access without the Father’s consent;

(c)     After the above period of 3 months, the Father shall continue to spend 3 hours each week either on Saturday or Sunday for a meal and an activity with the Child. In addition, the Father is to have access to the Child for dinner after school on a weekday. The Mother is not to be present during this access without the Father’s consent.

24     As neither party raised any concrete proposals for access arrangements, I left it to the parties to make the necessary arrangements between themselves. However, if the parties were unable to agree to this in writing within 7 days of my order, the Father’s access was to take place as such:

(a)     For the first 6 weeks, with effect from 30 November 2024, the Father shall have access from 10.00am to 1.00pm on Saturdays. The Mother shall be at liberty to be present during this access. The Father shall inform the Mother of the location of access at least 48 hours in advance, i.e. by 10.00am on the Thursday preceding the access, and the Mother shall bring the Child to said location by the appointed time, ie. by 10.00am;

(b)     For the next 6 weeks, and for a period of 3 months, the Father shall have access from 10.00am to 1.00pm on Saturdays. The Father shall inform the Mother of the location of access at least 48 hours in advance, i.e. by 10.00am on the Thursday preceding the access, and the Mother shall bring the Child to said location by the appointed time, ie. by 10.00am. The Mother is not to be present during this access unless the Father consents to it in writing;

(c)     After the above period of 3 months, the Father shall have access from 10.00am to 1.00pm on Saturdays. The Mother shall handover the Child to the Father at the void deck of the Father’s place of residence, and the Father shall return the Child to the Mother at the void deck of the Mother’s place of residence. In addition, the Father shall have access on Wednesdays, after the Child’s school, or from 5.00pm (whichever is earlier) until 8.00pm. The Father shall pick the Child up directly from school and shall return the Child to the Mother at the void deck of the Mother’s place of residence. The Mother is not to be present during this access unless the Father consents to it in writing.

25     Given my above orders for the Mother to personally bring the Child for the access sessions, I did not find it necessary to order that the Child be produced before the Court.

Other orders

26     While the Father did not make any express prayers for custody orders (despite him seeking an order for sole custody in his written submissions), I found that it would be beneficial to make an order for the parties to share joint custody of the Child. I was of the view that in the context of this case, such an order clearly affirming both parties’ equal right to make major decisions for the Child such as the Child’s choice of school and the Child’s country of residence would avert any acrimony between the parties stemming from one party making any such decisions unilaterally, which may inadvertently have an impact on the Child’s relationship with the other.

27     With respect to prayers 1 and 2 of the Father’s application (namely for the Mother to be restrained from removing the Child from Singapore until further orders, and for the Mother to handover the Child’s passport to the Father’s solicitors for safekeeping pending further orders), given that the Child was already overseas, and given my orders for the Mother to have sole care and control of the Child, I made no orders with respect to these prayers.

Conclusion

28     In relation to the issue of costs, the Father sought costs of $4,000 (all-in). The Father’s counsel argued that this application was necessitated by the Mother’s actions, that the Father’s application was mainly for access, that it was the Mother who made it difficult for the parties to resolve the matter, and that the hearing of the matter was delayed, with a number of case conferences necessitated before the hearing of the matter. The Mother’s response was that she could not afford to pay costs.

29     I made no order as to costs. The Father had expressly sought an order for sole custody and care and control, and never made any concessions in this regard. I therefore did not agree that his application was primarily about the issue of access. In this regard, the Father did not find any success in his requests for sole custody and care and control. I also did not agree that the parties’ inability to resolve the matter prior to hearing was solely the Mother’s fault. I noted that the parties had been fixed to attend FDR Mediation, but that it was the Father who chose to withdraw from this after parties had attended the FDR Conference. I also noted that there were only two case conferences convened prior to the hearing on 16 October 2024, which was not an unduly high number, and that the Mother had only filed one affidavit in this matter, whereas the Father had filed four of his own. I overall did not find any order for costs to be warranted in the circumstances of the case.
